output: Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Madam Vice President. The Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student who runs after the time is up before handing in his homework.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered a step towards the Commission's consideration of social issues.

The Commission President did not take the measure of the warning given by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, which would have unfortunately been identical elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These elections are reminders of the order.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a project of society and not just to adopt more technical directives.
The regulation of the internal market is certainly necessary, but it is not, and far from it, the essential thing.
The 2009 program, like the previous ones, will miss the mark.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to simply complete or even simplify the legislation.
They are waiting for the Commission to live up to the task assigned to it in the treaties, the locomotive, the Union's think tank.
It is not enough for this that his president is wise and silent, watch out behind the president of the council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the societal project that we need.
But what is the societal project in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any serious errors, but it is not the program that our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to take its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the peoples' calls than he is now.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, a question for the Council.

Quid de la conférence de haut niveau sur la Géorgie qui avait été proposée par la présidence française et comment la présidence actuelle de l'Union compte défendre l'intégrité territoriale de la Géorgie alors qu'un pays reconnaît deux régions séparatistes, l'Abkhazie et l'Ossétie du Sud.
But it's a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because in his speech he was not convincing, maybe because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he has made to us.
I think that the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he describes it to us.
Today, I believe that those who follow the internet can see very well that the stock markets continue to collapse despite the interventions.

So it's really for me, it's the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that brought about bankruptcy, that brought about a land to be totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, which led to underdevelopment in the south and which led to underdevelopment in our cities.
I thank the President, the Commissioner. The current financial crisis shows that when the problem is global, a global action is required.
And it is especially true in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is the reason why we created, in particular, the World Trade Organization, which we agree on, which tries to have global rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like, because we are facing a problem that is as follows: we need to reconcile two things, free trade, which everyone agrees is necessary, but also necessary protections.
And the protection of national economies or agriculture does not mean protectionism.
To do this, the path we have taken for sixty years since the GATT is an unbalanced path that goes from the reduction of customs duties to their abolition.
It turns out that, technically, the reduction of customs duties.
Quite difficult. The proof? A whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
This does not really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of many elements with very different origins, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as it seems.
We are therefore in a technical impasse and we are trying, politically, through negotiations, to get out of this impasse.

However, it is the case that technologically, we have invented, the scientists have invented a new customs technology, the customs technology deductible deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importing state.
In concrete terms, this deductible customs duty becomes a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty that the exporter has paid in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characters. It is repayable, negotiable, and transferable.
It is refundable at the time when the exporter will buy from the importer, he can deduct the customs duty he has paid.
It is negotiable because if the exporting company, which has incurred customs duties, has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or in the bank.
And it is beneficial if we want to help developing countries. The exporter can offer a higher amount of customs credit than the amount of customs duty.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer thirteen billion euros of international currency in the commercial field.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis gave the European Union the opportunity to assert itself on the world stage as a full-fledged and first-rate political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to come together and find coordinated, effective and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves that it exists and demonstrates its added value.
In terms of immigration, for example, the each for oneself was no longer in vogue.
The adoption by the European Council of the pact on immigration and asylum initiated by the French presidency constitutes a considerable advance.
On the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete objectives and lead the way for its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this subject, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish that this agreement is as balanced as possible, because it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very destabilized.
But also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To overcome the challenges that await it, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must offer us a solution at the December European Council. We are many who ask for it.
In recent weeks, we have observed with pride that a strong, united Europe, determined in adversity, listening to its partners on the international stage.
We hope that this new European mentality becomes the norm and that it lasts.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we have to achieve this. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Minister. I was in Belgrade when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan. And of course, I pay tribute to him for acting quickly and ending this war.
But this war is a bit of our failure. We have been timid for fourteen years. We have silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in separatist regions.

And this war, certainly, has awakened Europe by placing it before its responsibilities, but the fire continues to burn in the Caucasus, and we must do everything to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of the entire Europe.
And I also know the divisions, Mr. Minister of European Countries, on the entry of Georgia into NATO. And personally, I am against it.
And I will make a proposal to you. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
And only the status of neutrality can ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own.
Madam Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the last three days have been the European Development Days, where the food crisis affecting the poorest countries was extensively discussed.
The interventions have all stressed the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally using their land and natural resources.

By the way, the lyrical envelopes of those who called yesterday and today again to the reduction of state intervention, public spending, liberalization of all taxes, privatization, and the delegation of agriculture.

L'activité est quasi préhistorique. Cette volte-face, donc, en faveur d'investissements publics massifs dans la production agricole et la souveraineté alimentaire. Tout cela avec quelque chose à la fois de cocasse et de scandaleux.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Unfortunately, I do not have the feeling that this health report of the ACP, initiated before the paroxysm of the riots, the hunger and the disastrous disorder of the markets, takes into account the situation of the peasantries of the South and draws all the consequences of the serious risks that we know today, ecological, social, economic and financial.

I am therefore deeply sorry that the strong relationship between the agricultural sectors of the North and the South is so little addressed in the Commission's proposals as well as in the Parliament's report. The questioning of the billions of euros promised shows how long the way is still.
Thank you, Mr. President. The report that we will vote on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th last year that Mrs. Fischer Boel presented us with her proposals on the health budget.

After the report by the committee of experts of the European Parliament on the report of the Commission on the proposal of the Commission, here comes the report of the committee on the report of the Commission on the proposal of the Commission.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Agriculture Committee has remained firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we have judged to be too liberal.
I will remain vigilant regarding the milk sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abandonment of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of mountain dairy producers who should not be the poor parents of this reform, and we must be careful not to leave them aside, as they will need to be supported more than others.
I do not want to play the fool, but how can we imagine the French dairy industry grouped within a single region?
It is therefore with benevolence that I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund and the one that involves evaluating the increase in milk quotas from 2010 based on market evolution.

The calculation of progressive modulation made by the agriculture commission seems fair to me and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas, and to sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also congratulate the clarification of the eco conditionality, whose implementation had been a real headache for farmers until then.

I also wish that we keep the amount of the tobacco fund, which allows us to maintain in Europe our small farms as well as a non-negligible workforce in a region where nothing else is exploitable and which allows us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have shown a lot of patience and determination, and you have not wasted your time, far from it.
It was a real pleasure to work with you by your side.
Vous aurez avec nous été d'une grande efficacité.
I know that we can count on.
Thank you, Mr. President, for the work accomplished and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the PAC health report, by Mr. Cabullo Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, as we have seen too often, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious blow to our agriculture.
Decoupling, for example, is a real difficulty for certain livestock territories, dairy cows and sheep. And I am pleased to have heard Ms Fischer Boel speak earlier on this issue.
Furthermore, it is clear that the strict maintenance of historical references would place a huge obstacle to any possibility of reform.

However, I still believe that the question of the second pillar of the pact is an essential question because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the rural world.
And so we must think about this second problem without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouyet is leaving us, I believe that this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most assiduous ministers we have known.
I wish him good luck.

Thank you, Madam President. I voted for the report by Peerish on the integration of the OCM 20 into the old Munich. I must say, "death in the soul" because I consider that this OCM is not a simplification and does not increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for viticulture, for the entire wine industry.
Last night, the commissioner tried to reassure us.

I hope the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will be adequately represented in the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first one at the 20th century. Thank you.
And I must say.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, since the year 2000, initiatives have been taken in the direction of SMEs and I am thinking in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Glastoff on the SME Charter. Initiatives that have been appreciated but judged insufficient because they too often remained at the state of wishful thinking.
Today, we must go further.
The serious economic crisis that our countries are going through and the particularly worrying consequences for SMEs invite us, if necessary, to do so.
In this regard, the Small Business Act is part of a new, resolutely voluntarist approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine the report of Mrs. Herzog on the Commission's communication. But today, through the filing of this oral question, we wanted to call on the Council.
Mr. Minister, we have taken note of the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and we would like to know if the European Council of 11 and 12 December next.
Will relay relay its conclusions well and will give a strong impetus so that the guiding principle think small first is quickly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan, which is annexed, to take concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time I have, I will insist on three directions in which we need constraining impulses.
Impact studies, which should be systematic and the regular monitoring with the control of the European Parliament of the state of application of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
Access to public procurement.
The code of good conduct has no binding effect. We must all be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, adapted measures that truly open up access to these markets for SMEs.
Finally, access to funding, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Minister. They must also include support for the offer.
There is urgency.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's will.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ more than seventy percent of the European Union's workforce and represent ninety-nine percent of European companies.

As has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis because it erodes purchasing power and household confidence, and impacts order books.

It is therefore the treasury of the Smes that is in danger and it is therefore necessary to ensure that the banks guarantee effective access to the necessary funding for the continuity of their operations.
This is the whole issue of the conclusions of the competitiveness Council of December 1st, which the Minister spoke about, and the recovery plan approved by the European Ministers of Finance.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I wanted to salute the action plan in favor of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It indeed reflects the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to the small first, that is to say, to the European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said, and as we all say, the Council must really commit itself to the other institutions.
European Union. In order for this principle to be implemented, it is necessary to go beyond the framework of the declaration and to implement it in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the urgency of the situation.
And I would like to congratulate the French Presidency of the European Union for its volunteerism, which has allowed intentions to be quickly translated into action.

Mr President, Madam President, in exercise, Commissioner, I give my full support to the rapporteur who defends the position that was ours in the first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to bring our legislation on the time of detention into conformity with the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice. This has been done.
Le rapport SERCA apporte des réponses équilibrées et protectrices pour les salariés.
All the time spent in custody is counted as working time.
The compensatory rest intervenes immediately after the service period.
This is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, especially for medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social rights by eliminating individual opt-outs.
The Serkax report seizes this opportunity and proposes a progressive elimination of any possibility of derogation for the maximum legal duration of working time.
We must face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee is in an equal situation with his employer and can refuse what is offered to him.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the governments of the Member States that the text they want to impose on us is unacceptable.

And in the concert of praise that will certainly reach the ears of the French government tomorrow, it seems to me necessary to be interested above all in the employees who will be called to work even more, without really having a choice, and this, like all those who will be asked tomorrow to work on Sunday in France.
It is, moreover, to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its point of view on individual opt out at the Council.

My dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call. If we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, calling into question a European Union that would give them the feeling of not treating their daily problems, I thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. It was a very beautiful French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to disagree.
The twenty seven went beyond their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this first step, it is immense.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without sacrificing its economy.
It can now take the lead in this area to lead the other continents on the path of sustainable development.
Furthermore, Ireland proposes a scenario to get out of its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again speak out on the Lisbon Treaty, with all the cards in hand, since practically all the other members have already spoken definitively.
The current crises show that the Union needs more than ever the best institutional tools to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the most severely affected industrial sectors.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of the reduction of certain VAT rates, and I completely share his point of view.
Let us hope that the ministers of the economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, which seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges faced by Europeans give the Union the opportunity to reveal itself to their eyes, more united, more responsive, more concerned to protect them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having breathed new life into this dynamic.
We wish, like Nicolas Sarkozy, not to immediately review yesterday's advice, which ended at four in the morning to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the last six months, Europe has indeed changed its mentality, its magnitude, its credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency. We are well aware that it is not entirely foreign. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
What we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we are asking the Security Council to take a stand. We are asking the authorities to take a stand, the European Union to take a stand, and we in Parliament are discussing and we do not want to take a stand.

I find that, in the face of the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of extreme importance that this Parliament speaks out and says exactly what it wants to stop the massacres that are taking place in the Middle East at the moment.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote for a resolution after our debate.
It is for this reason that our group is calling for a revision of the decision of the Conference of Presidents and for the end of the debate that we have to have.
We will have to see on the situation in Gaza by a resolution that will demonstrate the clear and firm position of this Parliament, by a majority, for the cessation of the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution. We must be aware that we have a political responsibility in the face of what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion. It must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we denounce.
Thank you. Mr President, Mr Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal for a directive that Parliament is about to vote on arouses in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klink, has been carrying out a long-term work and has negotiated with talent, especially during the trialogue.

It is also true that the directive has made a number of significant advances, going in the direction of a better functioning of the internal market, of collective management of financial assets, and praised as such by the European investment funds industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament have never been completely free, since the outcome was known in advance. For some actors, it was necessary, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
On principle, there is nothing to complain about. The passport defends itself. Still, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies.
It is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, especially in terms of supervision of funds, since it results in a dissociation of functions beyond borders.
However, I regret that the system put in place is not only complex but also subject to divergent interpretations.
They are likely to soon encounter practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, the funds for exports, especially exports to third countries.
I have taken note. My position is a minority one. However, I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that only the path will allow to draw definitive conclusions in the matter and therefore to determine.
Who is right between those who trust the adaptation faculties of market actors and those who prefer a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success is at the end, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, the very recent news, especially the Madoff scandal and its implications on the industry of collective management of financial assets, is not made to reassure us.
Where skepticism succeeds my concern.
The investment funds industry will not be spared by the financial crisis. We are already seeing this.
It may be that fundamental challenges are necessary, that of this context of crisis.

In this context of profound crisis, we are making choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors, or that presuppose perfect cooperation between the authorities of control, which can really be seen as an incongruity.
I tell you, as I think, this directive is also that of a period before the crisis, revolted.
It is marked by a certain insouciance.
In fact, the financial system is going through a crisis of confidence that is both durable and fundamental. Entire sections of its architecture must be rethought.

Let's not forget that the primary function of the OPCVM is the protection of the investor through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting this text as it stands, without really knowing where we are going, we are doing a bit as if nothing had happened.
This self-centeredness does not bode well. That is why I will abstain, even if I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me to be of little weight in the face of the fundamental issues that I have just explained.

Mr President, although the regulation on the reporting of animals has been in force since January 2007, it seems that the Member States are not systematically complying by providing, as requested, annual reports.
Also, is a global analysis still random since many elements are missing as to the means put in place to carry out inspections?
Member of animal protection associations and member of the intergroup for the defense of animals. This subject concerns me particularly.
The associations have been fighting desperately for only finally in two thousand seven, directives were established in this area, where we see that the Member States display a certain laxity.
I would even dare to say a certain bad will, because we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouses, we know the farms, we know the cattle transit routes. So where is the problem?

I believe it is important in our time, when public opinion is increasingly sensitized, rightly so, by the animal condition, whether at the level of farming, slaughter, or transport, that states respect these feelings.

And since the floor is given to me, I would like to add, regarding transportation, that it would be essential to take into account, regardless of the duration of transport, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a transport of several hours carried out in the Netherlands in the spring has nothing comparable to the same amount of transport in the middle of summer in a country such as Greece.
Shouldn't night transports be imposed in these last cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Madam President, I am pleased that it is a British, our colleague Paris, who has submitted this text. As if the Roman soldiers two thousand years ago had done well to go to Great Britain and bring back large quantities of olive oil and wine.
But then we will have to draw two consequences.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to put the food agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not go back on the following points. First, restore aid for the shipowners, then stop the

The aggression that is made against the olive trees, and especially in Andalusia and throughout Europe, stop the aggression that is made against the fishermen of the red tuna in the Mediterranean and the aggression that is made against the European vineyard with the uprooting.
I suggest to our Commissioner, our President, Mr. Barroso, to organize a big banquet in Portugal with sheep cheese and wine.
Thank you, Mr. President. We have all indeed campaigned for the closure of Guantanamo and we are all pleased with President Obama's decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not be raised by us.
As Europeans, faithful to our values of defending the rights of the person herself, we must take our responsibilities, because it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we could read, and I am addressing the Council, we could read in the press that some Member States were not very enthusiastic about this welcome.
So I would really like to make an appeal to the Council, and especially to the member states that are reluctant to accept these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst would be that the goodwill generated by the closure of Guantánamo would not be undermined because we had not responded present when we appealed to Europe.

The European animal feed sector is one of the most important sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production, as it represents half of the agricultural production in the European Union, one hundred and twenty million tons, and in terms of turnover, around fifty billion euros.
The European Union has indeed five million farmers and sixty million households with pets.
In the past, the European Union had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of farmers, but also of consumers.

The provisions in this report have the advantage of representing a minimal cost for industries and a great benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.

The adoption of this report will limit risks by ensuring better product quality, better control, better traceability, and greater information from the farmer and therefore, ultimately, from the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international exchanges, it is more than imperative to strengthen any prevention mechanism so that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must be included on labels and the right to intellectual property, which is so important to preserve the competitiveness of our industries.

I think that indeed manufacturers must have the obligation to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering the composition of animal feed in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the control carried out by the competent authorities.
The fact of including an emergency procedure that allows a new dangerous substance to be introduced into the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Likewise, giving the farmer the possibility to question the competent national authority or the European Commission, in case of doubt, on an alleged unfair claim, allows to better verify the system, to protect the client, while preserving the loyalty of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to offer all my support to this excellent report, because experience shows that a regulation on the labelling of animal feed. I conclude, Mr President, by emphasising the quality, transparency, traceability and control, which are the best guarantees to prevent new health crises in Europe.

President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, let alone its High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, are they called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they do today for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan?
The Americans and the Israelis bomb the Europeans finance the reconstruction.
This is the distribution of tasks among allies.
However, it should be the breakers who pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks that are focused on a prolonged ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be overcome is daunting, to the extent that the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right that is democratically accepted there, may see its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future prime minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty, the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become in the West Bank a kind of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.

The last element to be taken into account is the expansion of Israeli colonies, which has never stopped since 1967, which makes the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks in both camps accept this truce from God that the two parties demand without giving themselves the means?
Allow me to add a reflection on the reintegration of France into the integrated military structure of NATO, which will be discussed in the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will entail for France severe obligations.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO, while the Cold War ended 90 years ago.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of the free nations.
Should we strengthen the logic of blocs at the hour when multipolarization and the rise in power of emerging countries, including in the military sphere, are taking place?
In addition, France's membership in the integrated structure will require it to strengthen its contingent in Afghanistan, when it already has three, three hundred men on the ground.
With what budget will it be financed, when its defense budget will be under two percent of GDP and more than thirty regiments will be cut?
Paradoxically, we are going to increase our budgetary participation to integrate NATO and reduce at the same time our military presence in Africa.
European defense dear to President Sarkozy will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
It was enough to read the Lisbon Treaty and its additional protocols to be convinced.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European way is a dead end that will only lead to an alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of defacement that we reject in the name of sovereignty and national independence, which relies in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Thank you Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this remarkable synthesis of the current state of our foreign policy and common security.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone else that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take its place, which is assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

The point is to note that, despite the will expressed regularly by more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you have said, certain progress has been made and I grant it to you for ten years, but it must be noted that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration was needed, its disappearance in the solution to the new drama in the Middle East would be there to demonstrate it.
There was, there always has been, a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in both the aid to the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the country.
Country and in the fight against the arms smuggling which had allowed to transform this territory into a launching base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the good words spoken in Charmeil, Cher and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

I would like to reiterate a question that was already asked at the time of the Lebanese crisis. When can we, Mr. High Representative, hope to see the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we had one in the face of piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Well, Commissioner, Mr. President, my dear colleagues, the decision of the Parliament to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the
The handling of this file was unanimous, both at the Commission for Fisheries last week and this morning here in plenary.
We are indeed all aware of the necessity for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, the CICTA.
It is about giving effect to the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to curb the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of the red tuna in the Atlantic Ocean.
Atlantic East and in the Mediterranean and to face the serious danger that results from it for the future of the species and therefore of fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Commission for Fisheries, Ms Fraga and Mr Rouede, were present in Marrakech and will speak on this subject in the course of this debate.

I would like to, for my part, remind of the importance that our Commission attaches to this file, which is at the heart of the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely the management of the
The resource, fleet management, compliance with international, regional and bilateral agreements, technical measures and, above all, control. I will come back to this later.
This characteristic file therefore serves as a test of the credibility of this common fishing policy in our eyes.
For this reason, it was obviously not possible that the implementation of the new recovery plan be carried out without the consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable way to implement the
Recommendations of the Committee on Economic and Social Questions, namely, that of a proposal for a regulation in due form on the basis of Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organizations is not, in fact, a trivial operation, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
On the substance, I am pleased with the different measures proposed, which, although restrictive for our operators, are adequate to the challenges and I stress that the most important
The most important of these measures are certainly those concerning and which will concern control, as it is true that without control, no reconstitution plan can be effective.
Thank you very much, Commissioner, for this proposal. I invite you to show as much determination.

The determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, when it will have been approved by the Council, that you have put into the conclusion of a satisfactory agreement at the level of the CICTA.
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to define concretely territorial cohesion.
The French presidency is trying and I would like to salute this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as soon as the Lisbon Treaty comes into force and that its contours be defined as soon as possible.

I wish, like the excellent report of Mr Van Nistelrooij, that territorial cohesion becomes the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the territories of the Union and allowing to make the best use of the characteristics specific to each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate the community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target only regions suffering from permanent disabilities.
It must, however, be based on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for the consideration of the outermost regions in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for including in his compromise amendments my requests regarding the specific challenges faced by outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, essential elements of territorial cohesion.
At the reading of the recent communication of the Commission entitled The RUP, a boon for Europe, it appears to me that it wants to apply to the outermost periphery all the
Recommendations relating to the improvement of governance in terms of cohesion, thus making the first illustration, somewhat anticipated, of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I wish that the general states of the overseas departments, which will begin soon in France, proceed in the same way and largely integrate the major territorial impact of European policies in favor of the RUP, whose added value is unquestionable.
The first is to be able to contest.
We are having fun reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last council.
And it looks like the victory communique of all the armies in disarray.
They have the audacity to assert that the crisis is over and that the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or to reaffirm a Lisbon strategy that is in full retreat.
Thus, as they become increasingly insular, Eurocrats, Europhiles and Europiomans of all kinds end up not being able to measure things.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter into recession for having experienced the lowest interest rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one that knows the greatest difficulties in terms of its industrial competitiveness and employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, by the general disarmament of natural defenses taken from nations, is the least armed to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the peoples lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by anti-national propaganda.
Only the states will have the legitimate instruments necessary for any major action and they will have to push the carcasses of the EU and the euro.

For the French, in any case, it is becoming increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French politics, no French politics without national and popular sovereignty. Thank you, Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that the question of the distribution of food supplies to the benefit of the most deprived is indeed timely. However, I believe that the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.
The question of co-financing is puzzling me, and I think it is rather the question of liberalism that has dominated the PAC's evaluations in recent years that is to be questioned.
Famine riots, the brutal price fluctuations of foodstuffs are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalization has always been done to the detriment of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers and vulnerable territories.

I therefore plead for policy to regain its rights, to take back control, both at European and global level, and for the strategic domain of agriculture and the food of men, both quantitatively and qualitatively, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Certainly, there is urgency and the Sikorski report responds to this urgency and I congratulate myself, but I wish that in the case of the reflection that opens up on the
In the future of the PAC, it should be recalled that the primary objective is to combat hunger and poverty in all Member States and in the world.
Rural areas are available to meet food needs with sufficient and quality production. Will they be given the financial and human resources to ensure this heavy responsibility?
Thank you, Mr. President. In this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continues to show its solidarity with developing countries.

Let us recall that in two thousand seven, the European Community and the Member States together contributed sixty of the total aid for development, making the European Union the world's leading donor.
European development funds help fight poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of twenty three billion euros was allocated for the period two thousand eight minus two thousand thirteen within the framework of the tenth EDF, which represents practically double the amount allocated for the ninth EDF.
The Court of Auditors in its report concludes that the accounts of the seventh, eighth and ninth FDs are, in general, accurate, legal and regular.
We can only congratulate ourselves on the record levels of contract execution and payments for the implementation of the EDF.
However, I also note that progress must be made to strengthen the control and surveillance system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Likewise, there is a risk that is too often high in terms of budgetary support, and it is, in my opinion, necessary to better assess these risks.
On this subject, I share the idea that budgetary support should only be granted if the beneficiary country is able to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible and efficient manner.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FEDE into the general budget. I will conclude with the Community, because it would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

To conclude, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the staff of the Commission who did an excellent job on site. And I regret, of course, the absence of the Council, and in particular of the Czech Presidency.
The president, the parliament and its rapporteur were forced to refuse a bad compromise. They were right to do so.
Our delegation has remained faithful to the position adopted very widely in plenary and which called for the removal, in due course, of any derogation from the legal duration of work.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one that wanted to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had gone far beyond partisan divisions to put an end to this archaic practice called opt out.
We were the only ones to propose a real compromise text that the Council of Ministers superbly ignored, just like the Commission elsewhere.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who strongly oppose any advancement of workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your goals.
The court of justice obliges you to consider all the time of guard as working time. You have therefore not lost anything on that side.
The opt out you want still exists in practice. The immobilists have won it.
More than ever, the deputies elected in June must fight to move towards a harmonization of social norms from the top.
"Um, Mr.

Mr President, it is certainly not in the name of the LIBE Committee, but it is probably in the name of my group. I would like to take this short minute to give my extraordinarily positive appreciation of the report by Mrs Pagano.
"Félicitations Madame pour votre rapport."

I believe that, by writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise checklist of elements that should be in place, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to everything that has been said regarding the importance of the training of magistrates, the importance of evaluation, to emphasize two fundamental elements in terms of mutual trust, which are the basis of what could be tomorrow's mutual recognition.
One, the independence of the judiciary.
There are currently a number of countries in the Union in which the independence of the judiciary from political power or other powers is not established.
This is a scandal and this scandal must stop.
Two procedural guarantees.

As long as we are not sure that in a number of countries, people who are suspected or accused of having committed certain types of crimes have procedural guarantees similar to those that exist in other countries, it is difficult to widely accept the principle of mutual recognition.
This is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it into this debate.
"Félicitations Madame Paget."
Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar and we will not be alone in condemning this situation.
The African Union, the Community of Development of Southern Africa, the International Organization of Francophonie, the Interparliamentary Union, the European Union, the Commission, the

The USA, a large number of countries, including mine and Norway, to speak of countries on the European continent, have condemned the coup d'etat because it is necessary to call a cat a cat that has operated in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we demand a return to constitutional legality.
We never ask for a return to the starting point with, if necessary, a decision by the Malagasy people under the guise of a consultation in the form of a presidential election or a referendum.
It is up to the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community in order to clearly signal to those who have taken power in a completely different way.

Democratic and in the form of a coup d'etat, as it may be, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantees of the future development of this great island of the Indian Ocean.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, naturally, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his answers, for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We have worked a lot together when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he also mentioned, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
And when I read it again and see all the disasters that have occurred, I think it is still relevant.
Madame Travelet, obviously, there is not only Greece.
All countries are concerned. And then I would add that there are not only natural disasters, there are also human disasters caused by men.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and how many others, industrial accidents of the type of Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters than fires.
I think of the tsunami.
We can fear one day a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, my dear colleagues, the tools we mobilize are not up to the task of these disasters, which will multiply under the dual effects of global warming and transport.
And that is why I think we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all his teams, the General Directorate, which makes the civil protection mechanism work.
I think we need to go further.
With the member countries that wish to, we can imagine a strengthened cooperation.
If we are not twenty seven to make this civil protection force, let's start with twelve or fifteen.
And you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I make the list of disasters, I can say that everyone is affected. The floods that hit Germany in 2002 and even the major pandemics and terrorism.
So, Commissioner, that is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States to go further.
And our Parliament, the Environment Commission, the Defense and Security Commission will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this summer once again, the Mediterranean forest was the prey of the flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and on a larger scale in Greece.

More than four hundred thousand hectares of forests and fields have been reduced to ashes, causing considerable material debates, irreparable damage to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human life.
Distressed by this repeated assessment year after year and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires.
I call for a European awareness for better coordination of efforts and mutualisation of anti fire means.
I wish for the implementation of a large-scale Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, and in particular the European information system on forest fires, a pilot project.
I nevertheless call for a reform of the European Union Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a powerful tool for responding to crises and a strengthening of the European force for peace.
Protection and the mechanism imagined by Michel Barnier in 2006 to intervene in the territory of the twenty seven member countries as well as abroad.

I think that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires lies in the exchange of knowledge and good practices in the field of prevention, and I would like to point out the pioneering role played by foresters and lumberjacks in my own department.
And I can of course make this example available to Europe, which can serve as a model.
"Bonjour Madame la Présidente, Bonjour Madame la Commissaire, Bon, je vais être court."
I think there are two elements in this debate.
The conjunctural question, how to get out of this crisis?
And all the measures that go both to the help of farmers and to intervention measures are necessary and absolutely necessary.
It is necessary to support them and even consider that they are more important.
This is what we propose with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a structural question regarding the management of the milk market, and this is where there is a divergence with you, Commissioner.
You propose to go in the direction of contractualization.
I tell you in advance, contracted between industrialists and farmers, in the long run, industries being competitive with each other will make us engage in competition at the European level.
We need public regulation to regulate a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate will have to focus after this crisis.
And I think that on this debate, we must respect all opinions and all options, and I fear that we went too fast at the time of the health report to settle a question like quotas, which.

And so far, I say to all those who have spoken, have allowed both to maintain a dairy production in Europe, to ensure an extremely developed dairy industry and at the same time to ensure a price for consumers that was so far quite bearable. Thank you, Madam Commissioner.
Mr President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I really have the impression that we can say that we are today more European than before.
I am really, fully, serenely happy about it.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the good will of the Czech president.

We must send a clear signal of accountability to those who hold the future of this key treaty in their hands for the Union, for our institutions, and for the five hundred million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be hostages to a few whose sole purpose is to counter the general European interest.
If it is legitimate that some wish not to go further in European integration, if it is legitimate to express these reservations, it is also legitimate to allow those who wish to progress to do so.
In general, the ratification processes of European treaties too often take on the appearance of a saga or a victory by default.
Are we doomed to constantly have to force the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We will have to draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, of course, from this commitment to negotiation in view of the organization of a second.
Referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to re-vote a people who expressed themselves sovereignly, and as if it were normal that an assent to a treaty could be a currency of exchange.
It is about the coherence and institutional balance of the European venture.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment a country chooses to join the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to the citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June 2009.
What do you think that today the citizen thinks of the Lisbon Treaty and beyond our internal coherence and legitimacy?
Sir, thank you, Mr. President, my speech is about the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the workers in the world earn less than two dollars a day.
Twelve point three million people are still subjected to slavery and more than two hundred million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of poor workers is increasing day by day and the International Labour Organization counts one hundred and sixty thousand deaths each year due to lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in inhumane conditions.
Of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes pushed to suicide, or victims of cancer or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to get out of religion, to work more, to stop the race for profit, to stop short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union's priorities in the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To raise the stakes, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our Environment Committee President Joly-Nainy pointed out earlier, a partnership of all countries, industrialized and emerging, is necessary.

Today, with our debate, but also with the elaboration of a resolution by our Parliament, we call again on the European Union to maintain its role as a leader in this necessary policy to combat climate change.
Let's remember that it is appropriate for us to speak with one voice in order to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach Copenhagen with an agreement to limit the increase of the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must in Copenhagen sign an agreement to achieve collective reductions of greenhouse gas emissions by thirty percent by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to the achievement of the objectives.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, sustainable and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus allow developing countries to evolve towards carbon-free models.
Also, allow me to address two tracks that seem necessary for our future.
First of all, the establishment worldwide of a climate change mitigation financing based on the taxation of financial transactions.

Then it seems to me necessary to put in place a tax adjustment at the borders of Europe, which would strike the importation of manufactured products without the slightest concern for environmental protection. Tax adjustment linked to the

A contractualization and the transfer to the southern countries of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe and which would serve to finance investments in the necessary equipment to fight against global warming.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to speak in the same vein as my speech yesterday on the preparation of the Copenhagen summit and, incidentally, the ECOFIN meeting yesterday, which was not a success.
I will address you on the responsibility that we, as industrialized countries, have to ensure that developing countries can follow us in our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same abilities, otherwise it would mean that we all start from the same point and end up with nothing.
So, to convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously have to address the issue of aid, which must be granted to them and not wait for the Copenhagen summit.
At the next European Council, the twenty seven shall absolutely agree on the way in which the European Union designs aid for developing countries in the important context of climate change.
Yesterday, I was saying that the ECOFIN Council, the finance ministers, did not manage to find a common position on this issue.
However, we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission had already made proposals. I absolutely wish that we take the lead in training our partners towards a global solidarity necessary to overcome this problem of climate change.
The efforts of the Swedish presidency to achieve an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the strong pessimism that is blowing on these future negotiations.
For my part, I think that it is not realistic to admit at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is dead or that it will not lead to a conclusive agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let us not give in to pessimism too quickly.
I plead for this. At this stage, we do not lower our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious and binding global political agreement, opening the way to the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is really too early to mention the expiration of the COP16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will.
We need to clarify our financial and development aid commitments, especially in terms of technology transfer.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is essential.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given to the debate by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway in particular, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

If we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only beginning to take climate issues into account, we will still have to achieve quantified, binding, and ambitious short-, medium-, and long-term commitments from other major polluters such as the United States and China.
Otherwise, we will be facing a climatic, political and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know, and we have all said, the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations. But if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I clearly wish that the European Union is able to say no and refuses to sign an agreement with discounts.

The European populations that we represent here are waiting for an agreement, an agreement that will enable us to effectively combat all the climate disruptions that we are witnessing every day around us.

They will not be satisfied with announcement effects, non-quantified declarations of intent, and non-binding objectives on which it will be possible to wipe their feet once the media spotlight has faded.

At Copenhagen, the states will have to commit. The European Union, the only continent that has seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to have set precise, binding and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

This is the reason why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to take their share of the burden, we will have to draw all the consequences by establishing a tax on our borders that protects our industry from the competition of those who would decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans are asking our industrialists a little more every day.
I have as proof the climate package that was signed under the French presidency.

I want to give the example of national initiatives, such as the carbon tax, which, as Mr Pargneaux said earlier and I congratulate him on, these national initiatives are pushing for the establishment of an ecological tax system.

A sector like that of transport, which is among the major emitters of CO2, even if some modes of transport, such as aviation, emit less greenhouse gases, is contributing more and more to the fight against climate change.
However, this is a sector that has been hit very hard by the crisis.

If, as I wish, maritime and air transport are included in the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries will also be asked of other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, the global public opinion will have its eyes riveted on its leading class. Please finish, please. Do not disappoint us. Thank you.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions even more restrictive than those taken in Kyoto.
We also must call on our leaders to create an international organization such as the OMC to regulate issues of climate change and the environment, to create a fund.
Adaptation to climate change, in addition, of course, to public development aid, the creation of a maritime and air carbon tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We can clearly see the pressing need for global regulation of the environment, as well as financial markets and the internet.
We have the opportunity to open this march of history through the environment.
Let's do it, in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as responsible people without any grasp of the reality of things. Thank you.

Thank you Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, my dear colleagues. Less than two weeks before the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing about the success of the negotiations on climate change.
Some, by the way, already say that it will be a failure.
Major world powers are once again reluctant to demonstrate the ambition that the climate emergency demands of us.

So, by adopting the resolution proposal tomorrow on the European Union's strategy before the Copenhagen conference, we, European parliamentarians, must show that our determination is first and foremost total and that the conference must result in an agreement, certainly precise, but above all, binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, which will be found, must not be called into question.

We will not be able to indefinitely postpone the decision-making process until tomorrow, otherwise it will be too late. Hence the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, since it will be brought under the aegis of the UN to control the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must, from Copenhagen, be able to expect great consciences from this world, more lucidity and responsibility.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British Labour government and the French government to repatriate Afghans in an illegal situation to their home country.
Indeed, contrary to what some people have said, these people had their political asylum requests rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.

The migratory pressure is a challenge that we must collectively address, and this is the meaning of the pact on immigration and asylum voted a few months ago, adopted a few months ago under French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights, financed by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty seven to ask the commission for a study on this subject is a first step and Mr Commissioner, I wish that the commission supports this proposal because the fight against illegal immigration is a public opinion and particularly of the immigrant populations in regular situation. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to come back to a recent event, the Swiss vote on the MIDAREs.
Certainly, this vote took place in a non EU member state, but it is clear that it concerns a matter that is not foreign to us.
I would like to come back to this event because I also see in it the pretext to talk about secularism, and we never talk too much about secularism in this House.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism dominates the organization of our society. And I would like to say here some simple things.
First of all, the opposite principle of secularism is not religiosity or, even less, spirituality.
The opposite principle to secularism is religious communitarianism, which sets rules and laws above civil laws. Communitarianism that confines individuals within sub-societal groups.
Our Union, by its history, is multicultural and multiethnic.
It is, it will be more and more, and only secularism can allow individuals.
Thank you, Mr. President. The C-E-S-A-R program, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.
How will the Commission prepare for the next phase of the CESA program, and in particular, the financing of this essential program for the environment and our scientific and technical radiation?
Will the Commission follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, according to which a high-level personality should ensure the political follow-up of this program?
Indeed, it will require overcoming many legal, psychological, and technical obstacles by unifying national airspace and having the controllers of the different countries work together.
If Europe was not able to unify its sky, how would it be able to build a strong political entity?
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is more evident than ever.

These impacts, in the short, medium or long term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GEC in a certain national newspaper make the headlines and certainly reinforce the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to witness, act and correct the effects of this process, which is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this debate, not only because of the bold legislation that is ours in terms of limiting the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can really make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a taste of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting the increase in temperature to two degrees, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just passed a law that aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by nearly thirty nine by twenty twenty, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambition in terms of the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
I think of Japan and Norway.
In addition, it is also necessary to highlight this very positive point, which was the consensus reached on the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text has been obtained on the implementation of the REDD mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus enable the natural storage of CO 2.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly within the framework of a political agreement, the Copenhagen outcome must lead us to question the reasons for such a disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, to see a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe,
My disappointment was great because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, and all the more so when it comes to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must show itself stronger on the subject.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not yield results and our leaders have shown themselves to be uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Hedegaard, strong in her proposals and commitments, before the Environment Commission, will be able to bring the European Union's ambitions back to the same level.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Bodis, dear colleagues. To avoid caricatures, we have heard a few this morning. I would like to recall some objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular progression of the average income per inhabitant, and now the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership of the middle class.

More than ninety percent of Tunisians benefit from social coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is dedicated to education, so much so that this country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals in terms of primary education.
Finally, Mr. Michel reminded earlier that women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.

At the university, there are more female students than male students. Forty percent of the professors are women. One quarter of the members of parliament or local elected officials or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Thank you, Mr. President. The criminal acts of fanatics who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and their government.
It would be unjust to make Egypt and the Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, whose authors will be judged.
Let's not confuse the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country. Let's not confuse the actions of fanatics with an entire population. Finally, let's not pretend to interpose ourselves.
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we give arguments to extremists who seek to present the Christians of the East as agents of the West.
I have heard. Excuse me, Madam President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or in Ireland is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which previously praised the fripperies of metics and merchants of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now the last to be harsh with states that have come to the rescue of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of markets and banks and this massive aid is directly at the origin of the worsening deficits and public debt that these same markets claim to sanction today.
Here is the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union, and the G20.

All that the bankers have learned from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of resources, profits and insurance, because the truth is that the magnitude of this panic comes from a large American bank that benefited from government aid.

American and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to win at the same time on the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and on the CDS market, these insurances on state loans that are themselves the subject of independent speculation.
It will not be enough to regulate the hedge funds, which you are afraid to do, or the markets for derivative instruments, as proposed by Mr Barnier.
It is useless to create a European economic government.
The twenty seven are in the same predicament anyway, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free global movement of capital that must be questioned, otherwise there will be no progress.
Thank you, Mr. President. There is less than fifteen percent of the original red tuna stock remaining today.
Faced with such figures, the solution seems obvious.
However, we must not forget the jobs affected by the decision we are discussing today.
It should be noted that CITES does not have the power to ban fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, 80 exported to Japan.

By preserving the tone, we are indeed protecting a dangerously endangered species, but we are also encouraging a more balanced and sustainable fishing activity, one aimed at our domestic market and providing employment.

I am in favor of the idea of a red list in Annex I of the CITES, and although it seems to me that this decision will be positive, the Commission's help to allow a deep restructuring of the fishing sector.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is requesting an eighteen month suspension, accompanied by financial measures for the sailors and enthusiasts involved, by a trade ban.
What is the Commission's vision on this matter?
In addition, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, is equity.
How to ensure that ships from countries like Tunisia, Libya or others will apply the international trade ban with the same rigor as ours?
What will be the new control and sanction measures?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors. But I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the necessary adjustments to the implementation of these measures.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this directive proposal is indeed the result of a vote in Parliament. You have also reminded this, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal, as it risks turning against those we want to support.
In trying to lighten the burden on companies, we risk depriving them of the transparency and trust conditions essential to their management and the dynamism of their activity.
First of all, I believe that we need to be clear about thresholds and what we call micro entities.
These are SMEs with more than ten employees, with more than one million euros in turnover.
Whatever the Member State, this represents a very large majority of companies.
Certainly, they may be local and not very present on the Community market, but it remains that the need to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and that.
