Accounting rules, they will have to face them every time they want to deal with a banking organization, with partners, or negotiate with tax, economic and social institutions.
At that moment, the accounting rules will be imposed on them and they will have to pay, perhaps more than for regular accounting, to meet criteria that they will not necessarily master.
I do not see any progress in the fact that the accounting obligation is imposed outside of any common framework to the European Union.
This is not simply a problem of competition, it is quite simply a question of economic integration and Community law and equal treatment for all companies in the European Union.
That being said, of course, simplifying the accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives, by the way, go in this direction, whether it is the proposal we are talking about today, whether it is the international reference, the IFRI.
Teres, whether it is the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
This. These proposals were promised to us for 2010. It seems that they have been extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this.
Hurry up and do half the job. Because these three proposals, if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation, and it seems to me that it would be better, Commissioner,

And clearer for companies to provide them with a single and global response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying the obligations desired by all and the reality of life of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is prejudicial to our reflection.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that divides both the institutions and the European economic environment today and to carry out an impact study.

Mr. President, Commissioner and my dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and the other colleagues indicated, on 27 and 28 February last, the violent storm Xynthia hit several French regions, causing fifty-three deaths and enormous material damage.
The storm was of a rare intensity. It caused devastating floods on the French coast.
After Mader, Europe is once again concerned.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster, Brittany, Poitou Charentes, and the Pays de la Loire.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also, and above all, through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.
I therefore invite, and my colleague Christophe Bechu joins me in this approach, the European Commission to quickly unlock the Union Solidarity Fund to help the affected regions cope with the damage.
This disaster demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European Civil Intervention Force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, and especially our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur, Mr Leichtfried, on his text and his spirit of cooperation in this matter, and I support in particular his proposals on the financing of air safety, since we are talking here of air safety and not of air security.

This has been the case for many years, as our commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that the strictest measures in terms of security must be the responsibility of the Member States. I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security concerns not only travelers but all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to fight terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that it is only the air passengers who have the burden of financing the safety measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And this is all the more true in the transport modes such as rail and sea, where the states partially or totally finance the safety measures.
And I therefore think that we must remain firm in the face of the Council and defend to the end the amendment thirty two of the report adopted by our transport committee.
So I had another point to address quickly.

If I support the progress in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a unique and identical European system of security fees.
While respecting the common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to maintain their current system of tax collection.

And so, in states like Spain or Italy or France, the surtaxes are voted by the parliament. And in this case, it must be the authority to appeal against the laws that must act as an independent supervisory authority.
And it is the subject of amendment forty that I hope you will be many to support when we vote on it.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The report I am presenting to Parliament seeks to explain that, in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that, and volcanoes in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and the climate.
But it still requires men and Europe in particular to take responsibility to fight against what is called global warming.
My report tries to show that agriculture can at the same time continue to reduce its carbon emissions, reduce its fossil energy consumption, and above all, another.
On the other hand, to actively participate in carbon fixation to fight globally on less carbon emissions and more carbon fixed and sequestered.
This report tries to show that in agriculture, we should move from a compartmentalized approach, which consists of opening a directive every time we have a problem.
On the soil, on the water, on pesticides, what else do I know? And to try to address the agricultural issue with the ambition of treating it in a global, systematic way.

And in this approach, we must be able to find ways to ensure that agriculture, as I said earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but at the same time actively participates in carbon fixation.
It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is close to my heart, also related to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

And I think that this path that I am opening in this report and that I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary at Brussels, this path must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

Ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other agricultures, to ensure that it is capable of being economically, ecologically and socially performing.

So this report deals with a particular issue, the fight against climate change and agriculture. But it has the pretension, I hope, in any case, to open up other perspectives to feed in particular the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
And I address the Commission, I will address, and I often do so, the agricultural committees. I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
It must be based on objectives that allow citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because the European Union's agricultural policy must ensure both food security and commitment to sustainability.
In any case, this is what I propose in this report, and this is what I hope Parliament, in a large majority, will follow.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to first emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and provisional manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration. And in these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines that demand the total and immediate reopening of airspace on the basis of one or two test flights appears at least indecent.
So I believe it was Mr. Hénin who spoke earlier about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with rail, and I will take this opportunity to say how much I regret the air paralysis.
Has been exacerbated in some countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our subject, I would like to welcome the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the current disruptions.
And it is a decision of good sense in a context already marked by the crisis. But these aids must have an exceptional character.
And in this regard, I wish that among the criteria for their award, exemplary conduct in compensating their customers, victims of flight cancellations, would be included.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that certain companies abuse the force majeure clause in order to escape their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261 of 2004.
Passengers are victims of the current situation, and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not have to bear the financial burden.
In addition, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to refund passengers for unused flights.
And this is also not normal.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we have been experiencing for a few days. It is therefore necessary to ensure that passengers are adequately compensated for flights that have been cancelled.
Thank you, Mr. President. A frenzy, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, disasters, catastrophes. The words are not lacking in the press to evoke the closure of the European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, especially when we lament the colossal, abysmal financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

And if I am pleased with the possibility of considering the granting of exceptional public aid to the air transport sector, already strongly approved since September 11, 2001, I am no less perplexed by the European management of the events.

One, knowing that 750,000 European passengers were injured, including a good part still stuck at the four corners of the world, knowing that the economic losses are exponential with the passing of time, how can one explain that it was not necessary to do so?
Not one, two, three or four, but five days for the European transport ministers to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
Two, no one disputes the need to apply the precautionary principle as a matter of absolute priority. But today, as we gradually reauthorize traffic in areas.
Secure, unchanged weather, and while the volcano is still active, we are entitled to ask what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.

Three, an evolutionary action model has been developed. The evolution, according to the weather, the activity of the volcano can change from hour to hour. Who will continue to carry out the updated assessment of corridor security?
Should these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this lasts, worsens or repeats itself, which is likely, the management model put in place will have to provide greater coordination of the Member States and special operational procedures based on real data. A better

Coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of repatriation assistance for tens of thousands of stranded passengers who also have the right to information and assistance.
Or, until now, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken. Thank you, Mrs. Delvaux. Keep your word.
Thank you Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to our colleague Mendes de Vigos, who has done remarkable work in conditions that are sometimes passionate and always exciting.
The debates within the Commission on Constitutional Affairs lasted a long time. They were at the height of the issue and at the height of the intensity of the interest that obviously put the people.
European Parliament, whose major concern is the composition of our assembly and the modalities of the appointment of its members.
Once again, the rapporteur was able to gather opinions and contributions that were sometimes different and to synthesize, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the opinions and the opinions.
I wanted to thank him.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both concerning the convocation of the CIG and those concerning transitional measures for the composition of our assembly, are marked by realism, pragmatism, and efficiency.
I believe this is what, overall, on other issues as well, citizens expect from Europe.
Mr President, Mr Dalli, Mr Commissioner, it is with great force that this report, as presented by Mr Peterle at the moment, takes up the lines of the report.
Director of the European Commission's Communication and is also inspired by the European Parliament's resolution of April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisaged by the European Commission to fight cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new model of cancer prevention, and especially the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed in the communication of the European Commission and the draft report.
I would like to salute the work done by Mr. Peterle, rapporteur, in the drafting of this report and the compromise proposals put forward to adopt the various amendments.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the Socialist and Democratic Group, I would like to emphasize the following issues. First, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogenic agents at the workplace, and the importance of better access to

Information on drugs for cancer patients, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular update of very concerning substances, which includes carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods.

Containing carcinogenic chemicals and strengthening the control of chemical substances within the European Union and finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that may include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
Here are the questions we wanted to ask, while also providing our support for this report project.
Yes, thank you, Madam President. The oil spill in the Bay of Mexico is a real ecological and economic disaster.
It appears that irregularities were found in the allotment by the US Department of the Interior of logging permits.
It would be an unpardonable lightness, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not only concern the United States of America.

When we know that in the world hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states, if these permits are granted with the same lightness, this would pose a real serious problem for the whole world.
Elected from European regions, ultraperipheral and from PTOMs composed entirely of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly one hundred and thirty.
Total, distributed among the three continents, I must express my great concern here for our islands regarding the plans for oil exploitation at sea.
This is the reason why it is imperative that the European Union, setting an example, rigorously reviews the security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
In addition, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are estimated to be several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Wouldn't it be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that the platforms at sea are now under the jurisdiction of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international authority?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate a true global governance for the research, protection and exploitation of marine resources.
Continuity of the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the east and south of the Mediterranean basin.
And as Vincent Peillon's excellent report highlights, we cannot neglect either the potential of this region or the dangers it holds.

However, let us have the clarity to recognize that since the bombing of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is in a deadlock.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even sure that the summit, scheduled for next June in Barcelona, will take place.
I will not be surprised if in the coming hours or days we learn that it has been postponed indefinitely.
We should not, however, give up. The European Union must take on more responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot let the United States have a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by contenting ourselves with contributing to its development.
The development, stability of the Mediterranean, conditions our security and our growth, and for this, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.

A recent survey indicates that the situation in terms of food security has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and one in three consumers remains wary of the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying the labeling of food products in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to nutritional values expressed in percentages.
And then I am opposed to a mandatory nutritional declaration for wines and spirits.
We wish to see the elaboration of a specific regulation for wines and spirits in the next three years, instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission.
Here is what I wanted to indicate, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr President, Madam High Representative, this attack on a civilian ship by Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit could we give to a Commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters. It therefore concerns the international community. It particularly concerns Europe, which is on the shores of the Mediterranean.
Europe should be heard more and get more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe makes considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The good financial and budgetary will that we are showing is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take the means to make ourselves heard.
The brutal death of Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army arouses emotions and condemnation.
In front of the nine victims of the attack, civilians, condemnation because this reasoning in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

By doing so, the Israeli government penalizes its people, because in the end, we see with the strengthening of the extremes, moving a little further away from the ultimate objective of security in the region.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must give up the policy of force.
I would like to point out, however, that the strong media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the government of Israel will accept that this investigation includes substantial international participation to finally find the paths to justice in this region. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I congratulate you on the new dynamic induced by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were only for that, would at least have the merit of highlighting how much Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also congratulate myself on the positive remarks about cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the Union's requirements are always highlighted, the interests or positions of its partners are systematically underestimated or disregarded, whether in the field of energy or in the way it can analyze the Eastern partnership and the Atlantis aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also note that the firmness shown by most Member States and the Union in their speeches, the virulence of the condemnations of the violations of human rights, seems reserved for Russia alone.

The remarks are more veiled, the diplomacy more restrained, as if it were China, for example, with its systematic violations of the rule of law, were it not for the Laogai and this global factory in the face of the minimum European social requirements when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of the adage of Angusta, father Augusta, to the summits, by the narrow paths, for it is in this way that I consider the efforts of Russia today, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that for so many decades has bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has managed to raise the head of a whole nation, despite the difficulties and important challenges that remain.

So a little modesty, gentlemen Europeanists, especially when the European superstate does not achieve any of its lofty goals, despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of Western and Central and Eastern European states.
I cannot help but remind you that this Assembly has more communist and more tolerance towards the Soviet Union than towards Russia.

It is often the same people who yesterday advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common house who today feel the most virtuous indignation and the greatest shame towards the Union Russia partnership.

In this regard, I must inform you, if you are not yet aware, of new historical facts that will appear as a result of the progressive translation of the Soviet secret archives, which a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov has managed to obtain. Archives that have already given and will still give many.

The unpleasant surprise at the climax of the single thought regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really Mr. Gorbachev, and the forfeit of the Europeanist powers of today, which then wanted, with enthusiasm, to make possible certain Soviet projects.
To repeat myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests or common risks than are certain states that you are preparing to make join the European Union.
The Council President, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, an obviousness that says a necessity has become ineluctable, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I am pleased with the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will be, in the end, a giant step leading us towards true economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Could we achieve a true budgetary federation not forced by circumstances, but because we would have decided it ourselves?
Let's go back to the Council's decisions, which I still welcome.
The strengthening of the preventive component of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no real budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who violate it.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified. It is a regret.

Otherwise, I will tell you my satisfaction, among other things, with the orientations decided, such as the famous Competitiveness Assessment Dashboard, because that is what it is about, reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
We once again praise the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a tax on financial transactions, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed a few months ago, or even a few weeks, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a profound change of culture on the scale of the European small steps policy.
However, it is now imperative that in October, the states implement these guidelines in a very concrete manner.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a giant step in history or simply a pious wish, which we will all have to regret, and in particular a majority of citizens, to suffer on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this report, and obviously Parliament. All groups still need to discuss because there are problems, contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
So that's why we asked to postpone the debate and the vote on the Gallo report, that is to say in September, September 2nd, when it will be necessary to have the conference of the presidents.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let it ripen in the summer and discuss in September.

Thank you Madam President. I admit to having difficulty following my colleagues who like to show their muscles and take advantage of the monopoly of our legitimacy in the face of the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this House, by dint of work and conviction, affirm a position, argue it.
We are defending what resembles a European general interest against tough states. The situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, Parliament played this role.
On the subject of the European Risk Systemic Committee, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur of my group, I defended, like the rapporteur, Mrs. Goulard, an ambitious line.
I have taken measures to ensure a certain level of efficiency and I have insisted on the primacy of the European Central Bank.
Why not?
Because the European Central Bank is the only community institution in this set-up and because it has shown its seriousness.
By Christian charity, I will list the names of all the institutions and all these great personalities who suddenly disappeared during the storm.
We can declare ourselves happy to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow the macro prudential surveillance backed by a strong community institution, while micro prudential surveillance will necessarily remain fragmented.
In the meantime, the European Systemic Risk Committee must get to work as quickly as possible.
The future will show if adjustments are necessary, but it is essential to start on a healthy basis, because systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The final agreement reached on the revision of the directives concerning industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.

This final package includes the key points of the position that I defended with several of my colleagues in the Environment Commission and which aimed to make this text an ambitious but realistic legislation.
Firstly, the maintenance of a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities for the granting of derogations.
Next, I would like to salute the new version of the ESM, which is so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better coordination with the ETS directive and definitively removes from the text of the new directive the irrelevant idea of creating a quota market for SO2 and NOx.
However, a few reminders, and more specifically the provisions related to the ground.
The Sol Directive is still pending, so this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by the Member States that have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement found at the end of the trilogues.

A huge amount of work has been done from all sides to avoid the text being sent back to conciliation. A text that, I must remind you, is of crucial importance, both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, every day brings us a new batch of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico with the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind are taking place elsewhere in the world.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and for a long time now, in Nigeria.
That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I think it is necessary to promote stricter rules for the management of platforms, not only European rules, but also international rules.
As far as the European Union is concerned, I think it is necessary for it to equip itself with a preventive fight against this disaster, and I think it is obvious.
I also believe that all of these are calling for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies, as Mrs. Damanaki said.
And the European Union should set an example in this regard.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tons of beef.
A new opening of our market would be made at the expense of the breeders of the European disadvantaged areas, without guarantee of respect for sanitary and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe buys thirty eight million tons of soy and cattle feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies, Cargill, ADM, and Bunge.
Between two thousand one and two thousand four, soybeans destroyed more than one two million hectares of equatorial rainforest.
This was one of the main causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in vegetable proteins for cattle feed.
An environmentally friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be nullified by this bilateral agreement project.
Once again, the European Commission is putting its agriculture and its farmers at risk in order to obtain random benefits for service companies.
These concessions will not benefit the peasant families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be convinced of this, it is enough to read the report of the Tyson group, an American company, a major player in the international meat market.
Who announces having invested in Brazil for, I quote, and it is in his report, to use this country as a platform for exporting to Europe.
Other companies, such as the company Dou, had already anticipated this approach by buying the Brazilian group Franco Sul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, especially in Brittany, had paid the price of this operation.
Europe, without wanting to pursue its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks.
"Contre les paysans, nous devons arrêter."
Yes, Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is to be feared, indeed, and as a member of parliament from an ultra-peripheral region, I have the experience of agreements on bananas. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with the Mercosur will have a difficult impact on many European agricultural sectors.
This is the reason why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
It is also to be feared that this agreement turns the agriculture of Mercosur a little too much towards a productivist agriculture to the detriment of small farms that exist in these countries.

A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers anchored essentially on the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would simply like to tell you that we may not have done our agenda well today.
If we let free trade agreements enter the territory of Europe, products that do not respect our social or environmental standards, the reform of the PAC will be useless.
In a very clear way, we cannot remain in an hypocrisy where, on one hand, we impose environmental, health, and safety traceability constraints.
To our farmers, for the reason that we must protect consumers and, on the other hand, leave products that can freely enter our continent without respecting these.
The question that is being asked behind the negotiations with Mercosur is indeed this one.

And the way in which things were initiated, whatever we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that things went on in the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to have a positive appreciation of a negotiation that takes place while negotiations are still ongoing at the OMC.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection and farmer protection, I do not believe that we should not continue in this direction.

Thank you Madam President, I would also like to salute the work that has been done by the rapporteur, Mr Bové, salute the Commissioner and then the intervention of Mr DASS who preceded me on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important that we are well aware that in the debate that we have, we have to solve a problem related to the volatility of agricultural prices and related especially to the fact that when the prices
Increases. They are very quickly reflected at the distribution level. But when prices fall at the production level, there is no repercussion on consumers.
So there is indeed an organizational problem in the supply chain, there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is called added value within the supply chain.

And I think that the report of Jose Bové offers on several points perspectives that must be highlighted. And there, I am really addressing the Commission to try to get out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the industry and the balance of power within it.
What are the proposals that we are making so that producers, gathered, organized, and more weight within the industry to negotiate?
This is the question you mentioned, Commissioner of Interprofessional Relations, but it is also a question asked about the contractual basis that will be established.
I plead and it is in the report that this contractual basis is a European framework.
We cannot let each country solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, a track, inseparable for me.
Secondly, of course, the issue of price transparency.
And on this matter, I am in favor of the establishment of this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers of the evolution of prices.
So I support the proposals that are made and I hope, as Mr. Deste said, that there will be a majority to follow.

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to appreciate and value its regional diversity.
In these times of negotiation of the new framework programs, two thousand fourteen, two thousand twenty, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
The issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, isolated or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must set up the instruments capable of making all areas of community action coexist in synergy in order to strengthen their added value.

Furthermore, as a representative of the peripheral regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new strategy of the Union for the UPP, which the Commission's services have promised us for the beginning of twenty eleven.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I agree with my colleague's position on the absence of the Council at this Parliament meeting.
I find it a little bit irresponsible on the part of the Council. I also want to say it.
As the next summit on October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already busy in this same cycle, urging Europe to do everything to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not live up to our hopes and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, or even more alive.

So, in order for us to be able to today, to force or convince our partners, we must show that our determination is absolutely intact, show, for example, that we are giving the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing and I heard yesterday the speech of President Sarkozy at the UN becomes a necessary evidence.
For example, the introduction of a carbon tax on our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that do not go far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat, ultimately, and a means of protecting our jobs and our companies, especially to better address the post-crisis.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalue family leave is not to be proven. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be completely demeaning when comparing the economic impact to the difficult-to-quantify qualitative benefits.

But the problem is essentially twofold: firstly, the economic context, which is true but not sufficient to leave millions of families in limbo for decades. Secondly, the legal gaps in the report, as the text contains several types of family leave, the legal bases of which are not reconcilable.
Let's take the adoption leave, which is listed in the text under the same heading as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the willingness to give equivalent rights to those of biological mothers.
I am actually the little additional package that Mrs. Morin was talking about, added to the Estrela report.

If the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of all women in the labor market, adoptive mothers, who have become mothers in the same capacity as other women, are entitled to the same rights and protections at work.
These are mothers like any other, who adopt a child over the age of twelve months, no discrimination, please, as it appears in the text.
Regarding adoption, I regret that the text was so little explored.
He was not even informed by the impact study.
All this did not work out well, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these drawbacks, I will support the report of Mrs. Estrela, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenthood in a society of.

More and more resigning to the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose to sacrifice their children for their work or to sacrifice their work for their children.
Finally, we are not sitting in the Council, but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected, are not ambitious, tell me who will be?
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not to return to the debate as it has unfolded up to this point.

We discussed a 2011 budget with the constraints that we know, that is to say, those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These public deficits at the national level constrain the European deficit, where these deficits at the national level must give a new orientation and a new impetus at the European level.
That is the question.
And I ask you, Commissioner, above all, to try to think when we discuss a budgetary revision, when we are going to start talking about the budgetary perspectives for the post-2013, not to.
To remain totally impregnated by the context of the crisis, except to tell myself and to tell all the citizens of Europe that Europe will definitely remain in the crisis for a long time.
All our problem is indeed to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and our debt, but it is also to prepare the exit from the crisis.
And this is where the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to get out of the crisis and this has been said by Jose Manuel Barroso immediately that if the European budget, because it is European, is able to give us the means to regain what we lack today in growth, in job creation, in innovation, in research.

This is the challenge, and it is at this juncture that we must discuss the budget and not, as we too often do, constantly integrate the issue of the crisis, the issue of deficits. And here, the Council is excellent.

I have noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed with Mr. van Rompuy anything at all, to sanction all the states that would not respect tomorrow a budgetary discipline.
This is where we are at the Council today, while Parliament is asking for one thing, and in particular the Commission, is to try to pull the European project, and that is done through the budget.
So you have noted a number of things on which we are quite in agreement.
There is a need for more flexibility.
Obviously, we need to find together a capacity to have a much more flexible budget, because it is a necessity, it is the reactivity of Europe that is at stake.
It is also, of course, a question of setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree, it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need to have a timetable, we need to set objectives together, Commissioner, it cannot be just words, commitments, and actions.

"These texts, which are actually very interesting and that I share practically one hundred percent. But now we will have to get into the concrete, and in particular on an essential question around which we are turning, it is the own resources."
How do we get the resources we need for Europe tomorrow, not just for Europe, but for all European citizens, and to find together the path of growth and a stronger path for Europe tomorrow?
It's up to you, Mr. Commissioner.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation of the next G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers on European economic governance, on the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact and to better associate the European Parliament and, of course, the national parliaments with the process.

I would like to quickly mention two challenges that are facing our nations and that are facing the members of the G20 and that must be addressed in the context, in my opinion, of the next G20 meetings.
The challenge of the currency war is that of the volatility of commodity prices.
I think that on these two subjects, which are real threats to global growth and which cause very important imbalances on our planet, the EU must.

European Union manages to organize itself, to stop the common positions, to give itself the means to speak with one voice at the next G20 Seoul summit, but also those that will follow and in a more global way on the world stage. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, my dear colleagues. I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio for the quality of the report and for the ambitious proposal it contains.
So this also shows that the European Parliament is taking its rightful place in a debate that is crucial for the future of Europe, and we can only congratulate ourselves.
Moreover, the Greek crisis has been a revealing of the dysfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
So I take note of Mr. Fayot's proposal to establish a sustainable mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, and in particular, sanctions.
It is essential if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of states, which is not always popular.
It's constraining, but we have no choice.

Mr President, I believe that the report clearly shows the challenges that the marine environment faces in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, and research combined with climate change.
It is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected and sustainably enhanced, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its ultra-peripheral regions offer it the world's largest exclusive economic zone.
In view of such a finding, it is therefore up to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a great policy of the sea.
If it is not the world's leading maritime power that does it, who will do it instead?
But it is necessary to note that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with fifty million euros that one can pretend to occupy the leadership position in world politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a strategic position recognized since they are present in all oceans, it would be.
It was wise to give them a major role in a great ocean strategy, which unfortunately was not included in the report and I regret it. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam, Commissioner, I would like to return to the anti-counterfeiting agreement that is currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement raises questions also for the United States, especially among the officials of the American patent office.
Furthermore, seventy-five American law professors have sent a letter to President Obama.
He judges that ACTA, a simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
As the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, which still raises major concerns and is far from unanimous.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to have a very clear response from our American interlocutors on two points. Can the ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti counterfeiting agreement, which China, India and Brazil are already not a part of, and which the United States would not implement, would greatly lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Throughout the difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have not stopped advocating for the principle of equal treatment for fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds like a given, but this given has run into innumerable difficulties.
The result that is presented to us today is satisfactory.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr Gauzès, who, after this particularly painful birth for him, would deserve a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize that the issue of the treatment of third countries must still be observed in two ways, whether we are inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold in the European Union will be effectively subject to comparable regulation.
We can, from then on, more or less speak of level playing field.

It remains that during the transitional period, non-EU entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while the EU funds and management will be subject to the directive, which is generally more stringent.
The situation is different for markets outside the European Union. There, the European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third country funds.
It would therefore be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, because they would be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was not entirely unavoidable.

Regarding depositors, knowing that we will make the exercise more restrictive, especially because of the new responsibilities that will burden them, the reinforcement should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr President, I am not saying this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is not harmless. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also involve difficulties that must be taken into account.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, particularly at the beginning of the twenty-first century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in the care process, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with health professionals and to follow the treatment plan.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative, and tailored information.
Unfortunately, the revision proposals of the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not correctly respond to the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals open the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which appears to us to be nonsensical in terms of responding to the real needs of patients.
This operation presents no interest, neither for the citizens nor for the Member States.
On the contrary, it means additional bureaucracy, increased spending and making patients take risks.
It is for these reasons that we had, in the first instance, presented a proposal to reject these texts, thus asking the Commission to review its copy.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schlyter from the Greens Group, allowed our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I salute, to carry out an important revision of the Commission's proposals.

At the same time, we had tabled about sixty amendments aimed at better protecting the health of our citizens and at making it easier for patients to access independent, comparative and tailored information.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Committee has allowed to put more emphasis on the rights of patients to information rather than making the provision of information an option for the pharmaceutical industry.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our position of rejection of the texts and the substance of the text having evolved in a good direction over the last few months.
The report project, as modified, managed to counterbalance the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse that health professionals can be instrumentalized to distribute to their patients brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any control by health authorities.
Likewise, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, especially in the field of vaccination.
Information cannot come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

The experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, moreover, and I conclude, what happened with the medications mediators shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this balance point, as we have sought with this report project,

Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, Minister. Unity and realism will be declined, at least I hope so, during the vote tomorrow on our resolution on this sixteenth Conference of the Parties on climate change.

I hope that our Commissioner in charge will be able to achieve the pragmatic objectives that we will have to achieve collectively, but also defend the sinecures imposed by Europe that are associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of equity of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is too little protected will be essential.

Green technologies must benefit the greatest number of people, but we must not, for that matter, neglect our present and future knowledge, and this is all the more so for this essential struggle against climate change.

Likewise, asking for common methods of calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standards, seems to be a legitimate request and not a weapon of negotiation.
Finally, more controversial, and my colleague mentioned it earlier, the shortcomings of the current system of proper development mechanisms will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the real negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.
But the will of many European MEPs, including myself, to work and participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have seen in recent days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, it must be the same for all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Also, is it not hoped that these agreements will be signed as soon as possible?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Obviously, there are divergent views on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these divergent views persist, ACP countries will continue to refuse to sign them.
Wouldn't it be better to go further in dialogue and understanding, by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategies, whereas Europe often responds only by opening up markets.
It is this listening that is required by the parliamentary joint assembly, the ACP, the European Union.
I think that the other European bodies should proceed in the same way if we want to build a real strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are probably one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the objective is their pure and simple departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation that we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and commercial partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation at the situation.
Discrimination, whatever it may be, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will only be victorious in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
My colleagues, we are all concerned about the serious crisis that is currently affecting Ivory Coast.

It is clear that the decision of the constitutional council of this country to question, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Parliamentary Assembly, the European ACP, the COWAS and soon, certainly the European Parliament demand the respect of the official proclamation of the

Les résultats des élections et l'installation du nouveau président de la République, tel que l'a reconnu la commission indépendante électorale, commission indépendante électorale qui, je le rappelle, est une instance validée par l'ONU.
All the political groups of the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for the prevention of any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social and economic disaster for Ivory Coast, which must be avoided at all costs.

Thank you Madam President, I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done an outstanding job and who have added a significant value to the European Parliament's text, initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we are preparing for the EP to vote on with enthusiasm is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let's not be mistaken, this instrument can truly change the European political landscape, as long as we use it with both responsibility and audacity. I repeat, responsibility and audacity.
It can contribute to making European citizens directly involved in the European political debate.
It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women, citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take a stand together and gather on truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our Member States to take the necessary measures quickly, so as not to disappoint our fellow citizens. This is about strengthening European democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like, in my turn, like several of our colleagues, to address the issue of the persecution of Christians all over the world, especially Christians in the East.
There is no need to remind of the horrible acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to solemnly remind you that defending Christians in the East, as everywhere in the world, is about advocating for religious freedom, diversity, and tolerance.

Beliefs. It is to plead for freedom, democracy and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, in any case, we are all convinced here of universal values.
It is really time now, beyond the indignation, the emotions, the solemn condemnations. Of course, it is really time now to move from words to actions.
And so I am urgently calling on the European Union authorities, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our governments, the foreign affairs ministers.
Engage precise measures to implement a concrete action plan to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
And allowing a no-go zone to be established at the gates of Europe is a danger that we must fight firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are multiplying and threatening the lives of civilians.
In turn, I deplore the loss of human lives and the taking of hostages and am concerned for the European nationals on the ground.
Until now, Morocco was a key player in the fight against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms, and human traffickers bypass Morocco, passing through Mauritania towards the Canary Islands, heading for the European Union.
It is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help these states to put an end to these threats.
The security of Europe is played on our territory, but also in its immediate vicinity.
It is time for us to act and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help the return to security in Sahel.
I have been told, but I join the marks of sympathy and support that have already been expressed towards the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
It is a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as I said, has been noticed for its lack of reaction, must be on the side of the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them carry out the opening of their country to reforms and to establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in engaging a peaceful transition, preparing for the upcoming elections, gaining freedom, and allowing the Tunisian people to find prosperity, social development, and peace. An economy that will enable the youth to find employment.

I will conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean has an important challenge to meet because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave in all the states of the Maghreb, the Middle East and the Near East.
It must implement a strong strategy towards these countries.

But be careful, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded him on many occasions.

At a time when Europe is questioning a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and especially rare earths, we cannot ignore the immense potential of the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthen European standards to improve the functioning of collection channels, remedy the problem of leakage or illegal export of said, or increase our collection targets, but also must be the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
The citizen's responsibility is crucial if we want to implement effective legislation.
And to do this, my dear Karl Heinz, the co contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
The producers of electrical and electronic equipment must obviously be more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot exempt citizens from the waste they produce.
Our citizens must be actors and not spectators of European environmental policy.

Thank you Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to share the remark that Madam McGuinness has just made on the fact that there is an essential link between the food issue and the agricultural issue.
The issue that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences that it can have on a number of populations in the world, but also in Europe.
I would first like to try to share a finding.

The tendency to increase agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials is a tendency for me long and which will last for three essential reasons, the demographic evolution of the world and the increase

The second element is that we have returned to climate change in climate uncertainties that pose problems, whether it is drought, whether it is floods. And the third point, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
So the tension on agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a heavy trend.
It is aggravated by the volatility of prices, and the volatility of prices is a consequence of the financialisation of the global economy.
And it is on this subject that we must also tackle if we want to solve the agricultural and food issues.

And to do this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, there must be transparency on stocks, but there must also be a public stock policy and in Europe, and a global stock management, especially at the level of the UN.

And secondly, there must be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, in particular by refusing that speculative volume has no connection with the physical quantities that are exchanged on the markets.

We cannot accept that on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without taking into account the consequences that this can have, since it is the food of the world and of humanity. And I end by saying that.
"That leads me to two major consequences. We need a strong European policy and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural actor."

And secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, at the global level and Europe is a player, we invest again in agriculture, because we will need all the agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on global markets.
We are only at three of the level of two thousand eight.
The decrease in production in certain traditional export areas due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for the production of biofuels and speculation.

The financial measures that have been taken, in view of the effects of the increase, are responsible for this situation, as shown by the reports of the IMF, the French authorities, and as the Commission also says.
The consequences of this new food crisis hit hard the 1.2 billion people in the world who live below one dollar a day.
Since October, forty four million additional people have joined these people who live below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what does Europe expect to take similar measures to those voted in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has demanded the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial funds on the markets for agricultural raw materials.
This advance is the first step to counter the appetite of speculators.
The impact is also dramatic for European breeders.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are in debt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth one hundred euros per ton. Today, it is negotiated at nearly three hundred euros.
The situation has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Confronted with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must face the crisis. I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of cereal stocks in the countries to make them available to farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to farmers on the evolution of cattle feed prices.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a portion of the aid intended to support cereals to animal production. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Are we ready in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a but.
Capital letters. The H1N1 flu episode of 2009-2010 showed us that each member state reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictional rapporteur on this file, I think that these observations should be made, but above all, to go further, to be constructive, concrete for our citizens who, it must be said, and it is indeed what seems most damaging, have undoubtedly lost a little confidence in public health messages.

The report of Mrs. Rivas, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which are, among other things, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, better coordination with the
European health institutions, clarification of the roles of European risk management structures, evaluation of vaccination and communication strategies implemented in Member States.
So it's a good report. I congratulate the rapporteur. Of course, it must not be a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, which retain the essential competencies in this area, to take real responsibility for our citizens.
Thank you, Mr. President, for giving me the opportunity to express my very strong emotions after the assassination of the Pakistani Minister for Christian Minorities, Mr. Bhatti, on March 2nd.
This terrorist assassination follows many other assassinations of courageous, tolerant, and human rights-loving Pakistanis, defenders of human rights and women's rights. I must say so.
Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed light on this assassination and to ensure the effective protection of people threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
And I think, of course, in the very first place, but not only, to Mrs. Sherry Rehman.
And I also wanted, once again, with vigor, to ask all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations in view of the
To prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, a clause on respect for religious freedom and human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, for your information, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate bubble and credit, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.

The Irish public deficit, the cumulative budget balance of the central, local and particularly the social security administrations, was estimated at thirty two of the gross domestic product in two thousand and ten.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself in the markets, wants to access loans from the European Stability Mechanism and the European Stability Fund, it will have to meet obligations for social and fiscal reforms, even though these areas are subject to subsidiarity.
In our opinion, this is not antinomical.
As a doctor, I would say that in case of fever, it is useless to prescribe blind antipyretics without trying to treat the cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is up to this state to proceed with a sanitization of its finances in order to fill its excessive deficit and to correct its previous errors.
This austerity plan should improve GDP by ten over the next four years.

Just as an individual, a bank without interfering in his private life and management, will condition its personal loan on a guarantee of solvency. Likewise, the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of a consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is thus that, by respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, on the basis of a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvability passes through the reduction of the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exonerating itself from fiscal measures.
Ireland is responsible for choosing whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to European Union interference in the field of subsidiarity, which would allow, for example, to dangerously impose a minimum European wage level, but rather a protection of the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantees.

Of course, it is appropriate to help Ireland, like other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, including that of seeing a state unable to repay in the long term, thus weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us have said it at the time, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and lack of effectiveness of the European sky.
And each of us in this hemicycle has been directly affected.
And five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without any real alternative means of transportation.
And a year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still being awaited.

A first crisis exercise, you said, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is scheduled for April 13th and 14th, coordinated by the Eurocontrol of the ICAO and IATA. However, it is essential that the ICAO assumes real leadership for the coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the London and Toulouse stock exchanges must be refined using more modern technological means.
These data, as we saw last April, can however be contradictory and can lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the AESA is essential to propose a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as to ensure the centralization and the good dissemination of the information.
Beyond the information from the VACS, the AISA must establish a data collection mechanism, closely linking member states, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all the actors involved will help avoid the chaos and inconsistencies we experienced last year.
And I therefore expect the Commission to be able, with the EASA, to quickly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the implementation of the European single sky.
President, ladies and gentlemen, this text is important.
It is not a revolution. We cannot say that everything was bad before and that everything is perfect now.
But all the same, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.

The main ones have, in my opinion, a better framework for distance sales, and in particular on the Internet. And this is chapter three, because we must strengthen the rights of consumers in this area.
E-commerce is very useful. It expands the consumer's choice, allows them to obtain the lowest prices, and also allows small and medium-sized businesses and artisans to find new outlets.
To move forward in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is to say, on a few very targeted points, to establish a complete harmonization of the rights and duties of each.
Very concretely, it was necessary that an Italian customer who buys on a Belgian or German website knows that he will now benefit from the same rights and protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will be fourteen days everywhere in the Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total of what he will have to pay, without fear of a bad surprise afterwards.
This means that thanks to the double click, it will correctly verify your order.
Obviously, all this will shake up certain habits.
In many states, there are subtleties in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, even though sometimes they cannot be found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one's habits a little in the service of the common and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will still need to be improved and we will have to do it in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andrea Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real fruit of this work is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all political groups.
The trust of consumers in the internal market of the Union is very fragile.
It was necessary this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number seven, after the first paragraph, a first dash, guarantee the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the right to life.
Freedom of speech and assembly and the right to peacefully demonstrate and to listen and take into account the legitimate demands of the demonstrators and to ensure their safety.
Thank you, Madam President, my dear colleagues, Commissioner. The open sky agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a step that places Europe in a dilemma.
The transport commission and the commission itself have underlined this.
Either we accept an agreement that favors European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits acquired since 2008.
Allow me to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, because the pilots to whom I belong are faced with a dilemma.
The European Agency for Aviation Safety, wishing to harmonize licenses on European territory, will do so to the detriment of the eighty to ninety thousand general aviation pilots.
Directly affected, some holding only one American license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of companies and jobs related to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security foundation.
There are thirty one times fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulation text two hundred sixteen two thousand eight allow for the provision of recognition and equivalence of licenses, which we do not see the interest in waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed in two thousand fourteen.
Thus, I propose a very open sky agreement and to invite you to accompany me when I sometimes come to Parliament as a pilot myself, to show you that an American pilot's license is quite safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our debate, I will necessarily be led to repeat or support some of the things that have been said previously.
But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems that we have to face, which the whole of the European Union is currently facing, cannot be solved by any single Member State.
No Member State should find itself alone in the face of the challenges that confront it, and which, once again, in my opinion, confront the whole of the European Union.
It is therefore really a capacity of the European Union to organize itself and to face in a common, in a solidary way, which I call.
