I believe that the time has now come to set the foundations for a true European immigration and asylum policy.
More than a year ago, a European Pact on Asylum and Immigration was adopted.
The time has come now, I think, to decline it in a very concrete way.
We have heard, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations that she was making.
I wanted to come back to this and strongly support some of these proposals.
Yes, we must at all costs strengthen the means of the Frontex agency.
We must strengthen the human, material and financial means of the Frontex Agency to allow it to more effectively support the Hermès and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for the Member States, which are primarily affected by the current intense migratory flows.
And it will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we must forge closer cooperation relationships with the southern states of the Mediterranean, support them, help them, and find instruments.
Madam Commissioner, I believe she went to Tunisia to talk about mobility partnerships.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a spirit of precision and concreteness. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, you are probably aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication concern the place of public services, public interest services in the single market, and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal twenty five and we ask you to go beyond a simple
Communication that would not be up to the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all stakeholders of public services, which would also not be up to the objectives that you set out.
The European Union must send a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework, either a regulation or a directive.
The Lisbon Treaty gives us the legal basis.
It is up to you to translate them now into legislative proposals.
I think that Parliament is ready to follow you in this way.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on this report, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The European Parliament's seat in Strasbourg is a question of European identity and it is not only a question of economy.

I am speaking about it today in this hemicycle on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of the Franco-German reconciliation is treated by some members of the Commission on budgetary control as a mere means of making savings.
The question of the expenses of the Parliament also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest that we hold the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels. This would allow us to make our Parliament's seat in Strasbourg profitable.
And since we want to make savings, I propose other things, for example, to abolish the Friday loss of our colleagues, also the abolition of the loss for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that we don't have to give up on journalists.

Let's not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budgetary control, although I would like to acknowledge the important work of our rapporteur on this matter.
Finally, since we are talking about the economy, I also wish that we moralize and that we cleanse the system of compensation for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it very moral and it gives a very bad image of our institution that the group manager is reimbursed in cash on the day of the visit, without any work, no control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes the sum allocated, I would like to point this out, exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for the groups to send a quote in advance to the service of visits, to receive a deposit from the Parliament on expenses, and to pay the balance on presentation of invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you Madam President, I will address the Commission, my colleagues, and I would like to welcome the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management in 2011 of the Schengen area.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s. On the contrary, it is a space that has continued to expand in recent years and now includes twenty five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it covers today, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
The mutual trust between the participating states and the Schengen area is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air pollution, the whole system becomes defective.
It must therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by reestablishing temporary and strictly controlled border controls.
By doing so, these failing states will clearly be invited to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level and not at the intergovernmental level.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all the measures envisaged in the long term, in the perspective of a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to plan more solidarity, and I conclude by saying that we must support the states located on the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years only highlights a gap in the Schengen acquis.
Two more minutes, Madam President. In a few weeks, migrants from the Mediterranean countries will represent a significant percentage of the annual French immigration.
This knowledge is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.

I hope that this proposal will be quickly adopted, as it will guarantee the fastest possible better management of our Schengen space and, in doing so, ensure the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions against Syria.
But unfortunately, it seems to do so with a shaky hand, carefully avoiding to call into question the Syrian regime's head.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as an indulgence that allows them to intensify the
Repression. A repression so cruel that we cannot imagine at the same time that Syria can be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the United Nations.
The United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities are refusing to allow UN observers access to the city of Deir ez-Zor, a theater of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria at the Council of Human Rights would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brute force against its people, in disregard of the values that the Council of Human Rights must be the guardian of.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options do you envisage to avoid such a disaster?

Madam Mathieu, a minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to first congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has made this report on the work of DORFERR. And God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen border control and they have succeeded.
Whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or control of air, sea, or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only note that this is the case.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement this Schengen acquis in terms of technique and personnel.
Furthermore, if no obstacle today prevents this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be closely monitored, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, the mutual trust between the Schengen states is based on full respect by these states of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates air pollution, the entire system becomes deficient.
I hope that an agreement will be reached at the Council in order to welcome these two countries into the privileged circles that the Schengen states form.
And we will all measure in this hemicycle the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have largely supported this objective, including the vast majority of Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have used the new proposal for the Eurovignette Directive to empty its content and block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to extend a warm welcome to Saïd El Khadraoui, and thanks to the tenacity of the fictitious rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

So, of course, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow, for the first time, to put into practice the polluter-pays principle and internalize external transport costs, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

For this Euro vignette to be more than a simple tax and to effectively contribute to the improvement of transport in Europe, the Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the collected money in the modernization of transport modes.
The Parliament has also succeeded in obtaining concrete provisions on the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives that our institution has set for itself, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt the compromise that is being proposed to us in the second reading, and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I agree that with freedom and brotherhood there should be equality with the farmers and the countries that have returned with the countries returning from the east.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe that we have made great progress with this report.
It was not easy at first and we were rather in a confrontation, but we have reached a consensus and that is the most important thing.
This consensus allows us to protect the global project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have succeeded in Paris and it was not easy, and I therefore thank rapporteur Morsison and all the Members.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for equality, justice, and equity between producers and territories, and I believe it is important.
We have said very clearly and we have confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, essential for the quality and biodiversity of territories.
I believe that it was also fundamental.
The fact that we have introduced this notion of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page of industrial, productive agriculture, is inscribed in the texts.
It will now be necessary to implement this. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, the concern we have is that indeed there are threats to the budget.
It will be necessary to answer it clearly.

Now what we are waiting for is that we actually move on to the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts, the grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are going, and that is what we are obviously waiting for now.
I would like to conclude by expressing a cry of anger against the attitude of Germany, which has led to a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was in the PAC budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are eighty million European citizens who are not eating properly.

Thank you, Mr. President. As much as the European Parliament can boast of some great progress in economic governance, I invite my colleagues to show humility, because we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be well aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament has remained inaudible in the Greek crisis.
Whereas we are usually so quick to react to all kinds of events, with resolutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I am very sorry that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, to the European citizens.
The second observation is closely related to the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these directives and regulations, we will certainly make the eurozone take a step forward.
More towards a discipline that we have missed so much. A step, I say, nothing more, that will show its usefulness in the future.

But it is only by seeing the heated discussions around the qualified majority overturned that we can measure the path we still have to travel, when it is rules and automatic sanctions that should be acted upon.
The mechanism of the qualified majority reversed continues to act on certain as a scourge.
We must, however, remain firm on principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left-wing benches continue to reject the principles of good budgetary management, against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and growth and sustainable are antinomic.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets like a good family man, but not by relying on public spending. It is a double poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the next few weeks are crucial, today is about rebuilding a union.
We voted this morning, after three years of work, a very important text for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
They rightly focus on online purchases, which may represent twenty five of all trade in Europe in twenty years, which is quite considerable.
These purchases will be particularly transnational.
They will allow consumers to expand their choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, it is also a very important possibility to expand their outlets.

Among the main advances, I would just like to mention two, the withdrawal period, which is now fourteen days, the summary of all the information and the total price to be paid before pressing the final button to place the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but all of our colleagues, voted unanimously with the political groups, because on such a subject it is not the controversy that we needed, but obviously the consensus.
Nous l'avons obtenu.

Mathieu Demun, welcome Commissioner, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to first congratulate our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult file, which required great technical skill, a lot of work and knowledge of the file.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we must face, and the technological tool is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
In fact, for a few years, we have been able to witness an unprecedented development of European data bases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the years to come.
The SIS, the VIS, Eurodac are all essential instruments today to ensure the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This answer is of course very delicate and Carlos Cuello had to face many legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles. And he has nevertheless managed to achieve a balanced text that satisfies all the parties concerned.
The creation of this network agency appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could take care of the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems. It will offer better synergy between these databases and will also allow the integration of the instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose on this issue was the location of the agency. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have applied to host it.
France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, which it has been managing operationally and administratively since 1995, and therefore has full technical control over it.
Continuing with the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new states, Estonia also wished to receive the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise reached is very good. A kind of distribution of missions. I end, Madam President, by saying that it was done by transferring the headquarters of the agency to Tallinn, where the tasks of governance, strategy and program design will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness report is strongly balanced and this compromise solution does not in any way question the centralized management of the IT systems. Thank you, Madam President.

Mr. President, the social clause, the transversal clause and Article 14 of the Lisbon Treaty guarantee, in a binding manner, social rights, and in particular the right to access general interest services.
It is time to prove to European citizens that the social Europe is on the move.

We must therefore give our social enterprises the space they deserve in Community law, while recognising the specificity of SSIGs in terms of competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local presence and rely on actors of the social economy.

Mr. De Rossa's report is an opportunity to affirm the simple but strong and meaningful principles of equality, universality, and collective access to organized services, which are factors of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it is time to move on to the concrete.
Yes, it is time to move to the concrete. I propose in this debate to really support a European legislative instrument for public services of a social nature.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution tabled by the Greens group.
Thank you, Mr. President. Debates on GMOs must be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientifically and legally.
On the legal level, the member states needed both varied and solid arguments to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur has broadened the range of market margins.
The French text to be translated is: "L'avenir de l'Afrique est entre nos mains."
The scientific basis must also be irrefutable.
The Council has several times questioned the scientific assessments of EFSA, which are always positive towards GMOs, unlike national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, should we not first, Commissioner, simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide a lot of scientific guarantees, especially in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why did the recommendations of the October 2008 Council remain dead letters?
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzyn for the excellent work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate ourselves.
This report outlines an agency with means that are more than adequate to its missions.
Recent events have shown us the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States and support for a strong agency.
Frontex finally obtains the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very efficient.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as the organization of voluntary returns or the processing of personal data, so that we can fight transnational crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's field of competence gives us the means to consider and address migration issues through a global approach and not to confine ourselves to a simple mechanical management of borders.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken up all its space in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish a consultative council within the agency.

I can only endorse this complete proposal, which takes a step forward towards a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continuous. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Meier, and the sometimes critical remarks of my colleagues. But this report on the 2010 activity is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Commission of Petitions, which remains too little known.
However, it is the Commission, which has a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, which can attend our debates in person.
It has an undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as a very long expertise, thanks to its direct relationship with the citizen.
Indeed, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend their rights before the Petitions Committee.
We can also praise the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often dealt with.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, attentive to the problems of its citizens and committed to finding solutions and protecting them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of weighing remain limited, especially regarding the environmental risk of projects that are almost complete.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will also carry out a mission in November on this subject.
I also regret that the national authorities are not always in a hurry to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it does, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for the truth.
I also want to salute the constructive work that we are doing with the European mediator.
I finally appeal to the citizens to continue to contact us through petitions as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to protect your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I am pleased with this resolution on homelessness, because it is our responsibility to remind people of the extreme urgency of the situation.
Let us first note that what was a priority yesterday remains so today, even more so.

The lack of definition and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting the crisis, as the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million, estimated in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned about eradicating poverty, asked Member States to put an end to the problem of SDF by 2015.
Today we are ourselves somewhat closer to our goal.
Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, been really put to good use by the Member States to tackle this great insecurity, whose urgency has become permanent?
I truly allow myself to doubt it, and I strongly deplore it.

To conclude, I would like to stress the need to develop a global strategy, a global, multi-sectoral strategy, without compromise, because of course there is misery and the lack of housing, of course, but there are also family problems, health issues, various forms of homelessness or personal vulnerabilities.
A global, effective, ambitious, but tailor made approach is needed that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their backgrounds and their life circumstances.
This is a fundamental right that many greats have been deprived of.
Thank you, Madam President. In recent years, as we all know, the European Union has been hit by unprecedented catastrophes, and the quotes here would take up all the time of the debate.
I will still mention the explosion of AZF, which we commemorated ten years ago less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A reinforced reaction at the European level, as proposed in the report of Mrs Gardini, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity between our populations.

And for several years already, the Union has been trying to make this mutualization of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and no longer wait for a new catastrophe to strike our territories to draw lessons from it.
Today, it is a question of making available to everyone our material, human and financial capacities in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we should anticipate risks.

And it is really regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for the prevention and coordination of responses to disasters.
And I urgently call on the Commission to review this position and to support these flagship programs that give Europe an unquestionable added value.
Here, I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her very good report.
I hope we will adopt it. It will thus open the way to European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to increase within the European Union.
More than forty three million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The time is serious.
Today, six member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement solution. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a decision of the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament called you up last July on an initiative from our Greens group and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but as soon as millions of people depend on this system, we cannot let the food aid budget be divided by four.
The urgency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, more than three hundred million euros will be missing from the food bank and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to make up the shortfall.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow a minority of irresponsible governments to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is above all a question of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the PAC.
We must fundamentally change our way of producing in order to bring food production and populations, especially the poorest, closer together, who are entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable pact will allow us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must return to reason and let those who need it use this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility to ensure the presidency of the European Union from January.
Come back to reason. Do we need hunger riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. Parliament has spoken out strongly the last time. Human beings are more important than finance.
Finances. It is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our appeal in a constructive way.
Six Member States hold in their hands the fate of eighteen million Europeans in need.
Six member states that claim to do nothing but legalism.
Jurisprudence is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not show our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm calls made by the associations that help the most vulnerable?
And we, European MEPs, representatives of all citizens, do we want a Europe where national selfishness sets policies, making few exceptions for those from states in financial difficulty?
No question of renationalising this aid.
No, let's keep this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not let those who, in the immediate future, in 2012, count on this aid in times of crisis, particularly difficult. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the Arcelor Mittal group announced the closure of some of its tools in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Liège, thereby provoking hundreds of direct layoffs and putting several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a Liègeois, I share the stupefaction and dismay of the five hundred and eighty-one workers who have been laid off from their families.
But I also think about the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same, poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, strong competition with imports from China, Korea, and Japan.
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automotive market and finally the gap in competitiveness, for example, of the Liège site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, and despite a difficult year, the financial center of the steel group Arcelor Mittal Belgium generated a profit of EUR 1.3 billion.
He refunded zero euros in tax, i.e. a tax rate of zero percent.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is mainly financial, with a stop and go policy practiced on several sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing else in the minds of its leaders than a variable of economic adjustment, where human issues are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, about the rules.
Wouldn't it be time for the Commission to develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational companies?

Six years already that our Parliament has adopted a report on the subject of relocations, the code of conduct of companies, the repayment of subsidies, and the mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions and public authorities.
Since then, it is clear that little concrete progress has been made on these different proposals.
So what does the Commission plan to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we need to support the competitiveness of companies and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we also need to adopt a legislative framework.
"Europeans strong to face de-localizations and restructurings and ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital."
Finally, for the case of the Liège site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Fund for Adjustment to Globalization in order to indemnify the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the wave of layoffs that is hitting workers across Europe should lead us to reflect on the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that operate.
Without any social ethics, which carry out layoffs and offshoring to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, please rating agencies at the expense of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of September 20 on the future of the adjustment fund for globalization, the Parliament clearly expressed its will to support above all the employees affected by the negative effects of restructuring.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure the coherence between the interventions of the FEEM and the industrial policy of the European Union, in particular through the use of structural funds.

We have also insisted that the future regulation of the FEMP include improvements in such a way that the fund does not produce what it produces today. On multinational companies, the moral effects, as is the case with Arcelor Mittal and Nokia.
Mr. Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look separately at the question of structural funds and the adjustment fund for globalization without.
To take into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from it, without examining the cost-benefit analysis of a policy, I repeat it.
Thank you, Mr. President. The European mediator is actively conducting investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our companies and our citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially against the detractors of the Union who too often say that the European Union is just a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsensical. Europe is doing a real job on itself thanks to the European mediators in particular.
But let me make a point that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire from critics.
First, there are the numbers. Sixty-five percent is the real figure, not twelve percent, of the investigations opened by the mediator concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors. Many companies come to us to explain their misunderstanding of the Commission, which remains deaf to their requests, especially for access to documents. Similarly, regarding the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people find themselves there.
And finally, there is, from personal experience, I confess that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Petitions Committee.
As you know, the European Commission gives us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and that is necessary.

But it happens occasionally to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer the questions of a Member of Parliament or who take refuge behind a wooden tongue almost as well as politicians and ask citizens to plead their cause.

I wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems that the mediator is dealing with and solving, there are Europeans who are relieved to be listened to, but are disappointed by these problems.
Behavior of citizens negatively marked by their confrontations with institutions, creating perhaps a feeling of revolt, incomprehension and, in the long term, perhaps Euroscepticism.
I wholeheartedly wish that these criticisms and those of the mediator against institutions in general are heard. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are the terms in which the subject of the day is presented.
So we, the PPE Group, have given our support to the report of our colleague, Ms. McClure King, report on the elaboration of which we have greatly contributed, and we obviously support.

The main recommendations of this report for more professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring the safety of patients and consumers.
But it is in terms of the path towards growth that the challenge of increasing professional mobility arises.
And besides, the forum for a single market that was held in Krakow at the beginning of October was not mistaken.

Who reminded that the Member States should recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation and should act to remove any obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Moreover, the European Council of October 23rd also set as one of the essential priorities to achieve growth, I quote, intelligent, sustainable.
Inclusive the implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, namely the recognition of professional qualifications.

And we see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unleash the growth potential of our domestic market, our domestic market of five hundred million inhabitants, of five hundred million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, modernize it, improve it, the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also allow us to acquire, we hope, additional margins of growth.
And that is why we have, in particular, I want to insist on a practical recommendation, we PPE, in particular, to provide our support for the establishment of a voluntary national register.
Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Kazmairak, for his excellent work.
I would like to say that it is important that every year the European Parliament should draw up a report on the work of the parliamentary assembly, the ACP EU.
This Assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening the North South dialogue and in the implementation of a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a rich year for the APP, which met twice, as its predecessors said, in Spain and in the RDP, to exchange, in particular,
On the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or on the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in two thousand and ten, the APPE also sent its first observation mission to the elections of this legislature.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, deputy from Mali.
This election observation mission has been a real success.

We were able to meet all the political actors involved and, thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, which is both ACP and European, we embodied a different legitimacy of European or African missions.
And so I invite the office of the ACP to renew this experience, which allows for the implementation of solidarity and privileged relations that unite the European Union with ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Darden for his report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but it is above all for our fellow citizens a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by twenty million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authorities.

We must more than ever uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010 during the European Year for the Fight against Poverty and Social Exclusion and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must sustain and optimize European funds, and in particular the currently maintained aid program for the most vulnerable, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and the dependent.
Poverty is a scourge to be combated at a horizontal level, and it is now time to act to enable the most vulnerable to get out of their precariousness.

And we must, as political leaders, at the European, national and local level, take the necessary measures to ensure, without discrimination, access to housing, access to health care, access to justice, access to education, access to a first job with a minimum income, which can be indexed according to the poverty level of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will allow us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.
The Europe we want and need now is a united Europe.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Le Vigne, for her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the points contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension.
Be taken into account in the measures aimed at combating illegal fishing worldwide, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires global solutions and the application of all states, including developing countries.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the States are also taken into account in the actions to be taken.
Indeed, we cannot impose the same constraints without adequate support on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
We must therefore support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
And that is why the Union will have to strengthen the financial envelope in favour of the fishing sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures aimed at combating illegal fishing are implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries to the extent that it reduces the financial resources that these countries could derive from the economic activity of fishing.
However, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic and education policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and companies alongside the beneficiary states, in the aid.
Having a holistic approach is necessary to curb this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, I would like to say that, largely thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe. Also, the development and implementation of a major policy on the sea, oceans and seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with twenty or fifty million euros, this will not be necessary or sufficient to achieve this great challenge.

The fight against illegal fishing is part of this great policy, and it is urgent at the European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, especially in the context of international cooperation.
I also point out that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, Guyana, Martinique, Mayotte and Reunion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not mention it, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular problem.
Madam President, I would like to first greet the Polish Presidency, which has shown dynamism and volunteerism.
Next week, at the Council, our Heads of State and Government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the eurozone, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously deal with the recovery of growth.

That said, we can see that today financial stability has become the top priority, and that the pressures, the tensions that are exerted from the outside on the countries of the eurozone, but also from within the eurozone, are damaging our credibility, undermining confidence.
And to hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, break the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts, and therefore.
Financial stability has become the top priority. It has become a burning obligation for all.

Our democracies have all committed themselves to very courageous programs to clean up their public finances, to reduce their debt. But financial stability is also a prerequisite for any recovery of growth.
But who says solidarity? Who says financial stability, budgetary discipline? Because it goes hand in hand, of course, it must also say solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this double movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
One last word on democracy.
Be careful not to undermine our democratic institutions.

Rather than thinking about resorting to a jurisdictional mechanism, I would say to sanction in the case of budgetary drift, let us think instead about control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

To be completely frank, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, and very frankly, even though I come from the same political background as him, I am not constantly, I would say, in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be once again completely frank, I have no knowledge of any recent statements by Alain Juppé in this regard.

To say the safeguarding of this common project and the safeguarding of the European Union and that in this movement to safeguard the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about the protection of the young generations and the preservation of peace on our continent.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Tomorrow we will vote for the third time on the new cooperation instrument.
Développement qui prévoit des mesures d'accompagnement dans le secteur de la banane pour les pays ACP exportateurs de bananes suite à la réduction de leurs préférences tarifaires, le BAM.

I therefore count on you to support the text. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Our coordinator, Tizbey Romain, cannot be present tonight for personal reasons.

The conciliation on this legislative package was long and tedious. And if the result on the human rights instruments and the IStGH is satisfactory, we are very far from the count concerning the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text reverses the mandate given to our negotiation team, which was to place Parliament at the same level as the Council on all decisions concerning the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.

By categorically refusing to recognize any power of control over Parliament and by using shameful blackmail, the Council has once again shown a reprehensible ideological retreat.

President, we risk shocking the most federalist among you. I think that a defense policy is an eminently national policy.

Defense is guaranteed in Washington, which primarily equips itself with American equipment, Europe being unable in this area, as in so many others, to impose its community preference.

Deficient or aged, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, each expecting from the neighbor or the supposed American big brother the efforts that he is no longer willing to make himself.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my support for the French delegation of the PPE Group in the Treaty on the Stability, Coordination and Governance of the European Economy and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.

This treaty represents a significant step forward in favor of more economic and budgetary integration, in favor of more financial stability.

Madam Ashton, good morning. Madagascar is one of the poorest countries in the world and is experiencing a political crisis. The outcome will depend on the implementation of a roadmap leading up to the presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
Normally, our contribution is close to fifty percent of this country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support to the ninth and tenth Fed, but not to the OMD.
During this time, the population suffers and the companies established in Madagascar are sometimes forced to contribute despite themselves.

While supporting your position, we hope that you will use all your weight with the Statedec so that the legal and judicial imbroglio concerning the return of a former president is resolved as soon as possible, as being one of the most sensitive elements of the application of this roadmap.

I would like your opinion on the matter and I also indicate that the friendship group European Union Madagascar, which we have just created in the European Parliament, is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defense of the values of our Union.
Mr. President, I would like to quote the rapporteur, Mr. Itourias, for the quality of his work, for the long negotiation work he had to do, and for the patience he showed.

We are finally coming to the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring back to this hemicycle, the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and fears of our fellow citizens.
Here is additional proof, if any, of the effectiveness of the right to petition in Europe.
Petitions on the environment are the majority and waste is a major concern of our fellow citizens.
This subject must address a societal problem.
We consume at all costs.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens, that is clear.
But this report is also a reminder for the Member States.
It is still worrying to see that the States seem not to be in control of the situation.
Only six Member States have transposed the Waste Framework Directive in time.
The number of complaints received on the subject sometimes demonstrates the lack of transparency in the choice of disposal sites.
Finally, and this is the most worrying, organized crime seems to be doing what it wants.
A market of seventy five billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
We must increase sanctions against companies that violate public contracts to enrich themselves.
This report is a warning signal to the States, but the European Commission must also play its role and verify the proper implementation of waste directives.
This file must be made visible but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money in the verification and counter verification procedures that may last for years.
Let's listen to the petitioners' message and stop this mess as soon as possible.
Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he has shown in the face of the Council and the Commission.

This agreement reminds me of the illusion that children know, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass next to sheep.

Do we want that for the European level?
I say no, there must be a mastery of production with the participation of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries differ considerably from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we uphold, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is essential that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specific and legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to guarantee themselves a right of access to rectification of personal data concerning them, as well as the ability to file a legal recourse in the event of a violation of their rights.
It is necessary to act to allow European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a potentially prejudicial legal conflict for European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot do without our obligations and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the implementation of a European Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and therefore the protection of the personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this direction and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, thank you to the rapporteur for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent more than a year strengthening its economic governance to avoid macroeconomic imbalances and budget deficits that are too large and threaten the European economy. But this has not prevented social exclusion or the increase in unemployment.
It is time. No, it is now urgent that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy be an absolute priority for the European Commission and the Member States, in a perspective of growth.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that the focus should be on so many subjects such as job sharing, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeship, paid internships, etc.

However, and Commissioner Andor reminded us earlier, we have twenty three million unemployed in Europe, but also twenty three million SMEs and twenty three billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment and not used.
We could almost make it a strategy. Twenty three, twenty three.
And that is not to mention the sixty billion euros of cohesion funds not affected.
In Denmark, social initiatives have been taken and have proven their effectiveness based on flexicurity.
Let's take a deep breath.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those related to unemployment and active support for all socially virtuous companies.
We had poverty reduction targets to be achieved by 2020, but we already know that they will not be met due to the lack of strong and adequate measures taken by Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy used to take strong economic governance measures also be used for ambitious, effective and restrictive social governance measures.
Thank you, Madam President. Undoubtedly, the women's cause owes a great deal to Europe.
The principle of gender equality was already included in the Treaty of Rome and has been constantly reaffirmed since in the numerous treaties.
Gender equality is a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has always worked very voluntarily for gender equality, for the cause of the promotion of women and.

Many legislative instruments have been adopted, directives have been implemented.
There is, right here in our Parliament, for many years now, a commission on women's rights and gender equality that is extremely active and vigilant.
An European Institute for Gender Equality has been created.
Programs are implemented, financial resources are voted year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate for its second edition the European Day of Equal Treatment, the Equal Pay Day.
European Equal Pay Day. Undoubtedly, therefore, the legislative arsenal exists. The European will has been realized on several occasions.
However, it must be noted that the fight remains relevant. The fight for gender equality, and in particular for wage equality.
There is always, on average, in all the countries of the European Union, a wage gap of about 17.
At equal pay, women still earn seventeen percent less than men.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Committee of Parliament is currently working on a resolution project to call on the European Commission to review the 2006 directive on gender equality.
Treatment, which is one of the most pressing and at the heart of the concerns and demands of European women in all our societies.
On another subject, the establishment of quotas, quotas both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within politics. I come from France, which has long since adopted quotas.
Ten years of restrictive rules regarding quotas in politics, and more recently, a year ago, a law for the establishment of quotas in the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So what is the balance? After a few years of application in one case, a few months in the other, it is necessary to note that things have moved, that things have progressed.
So a necessary evil.
The quotas have an effect.

Madam Commissioner, you recently took an important step towards the establishment of quotas at the European level in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this large public consultation aimed at gathering opinions on the actions to be taken, the legislative actions to be taken.
On this subject, you will have my full and entire support. Thank you.

Europe. And then a question to the European Commission, so that acts can be taken to address a number of our concerns related to common agricultural policy.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur and our assistants for the work done.
This report now bears its name very well, namely to remove the obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a great project, but we too often notice that it is not yet perfectly defined.

With my colleagues from the PPE, we have made a lot of proposals, the most numerous, and I would like to thank them for that.
This report must produce a sense of belonging and European identity that we must recreate and maintain through these measures.

I believe that taxation is an interesting tool to change behaviour.

The principle of proportionality of the different levels of taxation of energy products therefore appears to me to be a necessity.
And in the case we are dealing with, for example, this would allow us to put an end to the diesel tourism that we are currently witnessing, which is not an acceptable thing.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal to revise the directive.

"Volatility of prices on global markets and I think of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposal for a directive will have a certain differentiated impact depending on the level of taxation of each Member State, but an impact all the same on the price of diesel."

Are there any real alternatives? Practical, realistic, accessible to consumers?
As a fictitious rapporteur in the Environment Commission, I support an ambitious but above all sustainable positioning for all.

I therefore advocate for greater progressiveness and the implementation of the proposal and its principle of proportionality in twenty thirty, by means of a new impact study updating the one on which the Commission is based and which was carried out five years ago.

A few months earlier, here, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe under the effect of the economic crisis, especially at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European member states and which is restructuring its production tool in Europe in the face of a demand for steel in steel.
Since the closure of two blast furnaces in Belgium, Luxembourg, and the alert of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly six thousand direct jobs would be threatened for the year 2012.
