Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by refuting the unsubstantiated allegations of circulation in France of five hundred thousand to one million fake biometric passports that would circulate in our country.
France takes very seriously the risks of fraud concerning identity documents.
It does not treat lightly the delicts in the matter.
At the initiative of this government, identity theft is a crime that is punished with one year in prison and fifteen thousand euros in fines.
The conditions for the release of identity documents have been simplified, which has allowed prefectures to free up additional resources to fight this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud reference is designated.
Furthermore, the provisions for the security and delivery of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be verified between administrative services, as far as possible by means of de-materialized channels, in order to limit the risk of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the supporting documents of domicile.
The Ministry of the Interior has committed to the path of an increased security of home justification with the insertion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title application includes the authorized consultation of relevant files, the comparison of all documents produced in previous title applications, and the possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the delivery of securities is also guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant at the time of the filing of the application and then at the time of the withdrawal of the securities, as well as the taking of two digital fingerprints.
And without mentioning the enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France is alerting international cooperation agencies, including Interpol, to the issue of lost or stolen passports that are being used for fraudulent purposes. I conclude, Mr. President, that I have almost finished my remarks.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed.
Mr President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, a note that our fellow citizens increasingly want to find and consume locally and seasonally produced food for health and quality reasons.
We must find the means to allow farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructure for producers, such as the maintenance of nearby slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous sanitary control, allow the development of local supply chains and the strengthening of direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales must help producers market their products and make them known to consumers.
The strengthening of these direct relations will allow farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales within farming and support collective actions of farmers who wish to open collective sales points that offer local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, the sustainability and the development of direct sales systems by delivery to consumers, such as the AMAP in France, which allow nearly three thousand farmers to supply sixty thousand families.

Finally, the Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional character of the product, to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues. I am pleased that this rectifying budget concerning the state budget, which was voted in a large majority in the budget committee on March 29th, was passed.
By financing this overrun, we avoid throwing away a strategic research project of fundamental importance in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international promises.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners of the Euratom community has called into question their overall contribution to the project.
Despite the Fukushima tragedy, Japan has decided to scrupulously respect its budgetary commitments in ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have suffered significant delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Cadarache.
From 2015 to 2017 and 2018, the construction phase of the buildings and assembly of the machine could mobilize up to four thousand five hundred people on this site.
To conclude, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Madam, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work that we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major challenges related to the environment, the horizon 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh environmental action programme, by putting existing financial frameworks in synergy and mobilising new sources of financing.
This program must ensure coherence and articulation between the environmental strategies of the European Union and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture.
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is plaguing the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon any ambition in the environmental and climate fields.
Inaction would be fatal.
The issues are too important, especially in terms of the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco innovation, source of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco design, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products, in order to avoid waste and poor choices of consumption.
We cannot ignore this necessary environmental education for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a political programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability to national and local administrations, citizens, but also to entrepreneurs and investors, on the environmental choices of the European Union.
European regulation should not become a punishment or a burden.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the profound changes to which our world is subject today, the EU must reform its generalized preference system.
Like any compromise, this one does not break the rule.
If it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from being perfect, as we must bear in mind that this regulation is aimed at developing countries.
By developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its action in favour of the poorest countries.
This does not seem to be sustainable at first glance.
To this end, the Commission has nevertheless developed a strictly accounting vision based on the sole criterion of GDP per capita.
We can clearly see the limits of this approach.
Quid des nombreux pays en développement à revenus moyens dont les économies sont peu diversifiées et qui sont vulnérables aux aléas climatiques.
The compromise reached with the Council does not answer this question, and that is why I call on colleagues to vote in favour of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Mr. Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the different languages of the Union is not new, unfortunately.
This is a crucial issue, in my opinion, for which I have not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally written to Mr Barroso.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equality of access to information between all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its ruling of 20 November 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, according to which public consultations do not provide a totally representative image of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
This is not an answer.
I wonder about the criteria that would allow for the measurement of an overrepresentation of the European population.
If the written consultations are not representative because of the sole availability in English, for example, they fail to consult European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a wrong indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to keep written consultations as a tool at the base of the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must guarantee democratic, transparent and fair for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission opts for written consultation, it must take its responsibilities and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to include in the analysis the too short deadlines for the deposit of contributions, as well as the few means deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately not very accessible to beginners. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter and failing states will be forced by the technocrats of Brussels to implement budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced surveillance is called a guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, and perhaps even slapped. Financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent the only budgetary austerity by growth measures, your proposals are there only to pass the pill.
Growth, you know it as well as I do, does not occur spontaneously.
Without consulting the peoples and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the Chinese thief's technique, the bureaucratic, technocratic and totalitarian European state will have finished to be constituted, we will have lost our people's freedom altogether.
Thank you, Mr. President. Without knowing the importance of the economic choices we must make, you will allow me to insist on a remark of a more political nature in the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have again seen evidence of the double language of certain European leaders or those who think they are.
Alors que chacun ne cesse de plaider pour une coordination des politiques économiques, budgétaires et fiscales enfin digne de ce nom et que cette exigence apparaît même comme une condition.
The sine qua non of the survival of the eurozone is that once well established at home, it is Mr. Croix-Malin who decries the balanced recommendations emanating from the European Commission.
The Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to turn public opinion against these Brussels pacts, as they say.
This irresponsible attitude could be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I tell you very clearly, our debates on stability, the necessary cleaning up of public finances or on the efforts to be made in the field of growth are indeed aimed at the
If the legacies of the past in terms of debt and public deficits do not come to an end, and if the governments of the member states continue in their misadventures.
We are currently playing with fire.
European discipline must play for all, without exception, even for the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinions are ready for it, even if some of their leaders do not want to believe it.
And one last word to Mrs. Goulard, otherwise I have to show her the blue card. I will say to finish with Mrs. Goulard in redemption there is a lot.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to congratulate the European Commission, and especially yours, Commissioner, for having tirelessly put the relaunch and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

You were saying, Commissioner, that for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors for which more of the internal market is needed, more of the internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also finished later by signifying the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
And rather than constantly seeking to invent new growth instruments, we have every interest in working with the toolbox we already have.

We are seizing the opportunity of the resolution, which will be submitted for a vote in our assembly tomorrow, to send a strong political message to the Member States. More speed and efficiency in the transposition of directives already.
Adopted more mobilization and commitment in newly opened sites, I will only mention one, that of strengthening workers' mobility, more ease of travel, more fluidity of travel.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second step of the Act for the Single Market that you will present after the summer.
We will show both political will and the ability to put pressure on Member States.
We have known the scandal of the Mediapost a few times.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the dysfunctions of European health security.
This scandal of breast implants, these fourteen years of fraud from 1996 to 2010, unpunished.
There are 500,000 prostheses worn in the world. There are 8,000 implant removals, 48 cases of cancer detected.
It is finally three thousand five hundred complaints filed. These numbers are frightening, shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the American drug agency, Mr. Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and condemnations for prosthesis failure filed in Great Britain, in France in particular, how could national and European agencies have missed such a scam?
This tragedy immediately led us to consider an improvement of the European system for the control of medical devices, as you have just explained.
We must, Commissioner, today build a new system capable of avoiding scandal, but it is a new system that must be built.
It is announced for the fall. You indicated this new legislation.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as set out in this resolution.
So why make an exception? Unacceptable for a good number of parliamentarians here present.
Why not want the creation of a market authorization for the most risky class three medical devices?
Mr. Commissioner Dalli, can you explain your position?
Mr. President, currently, we are experiencing a situation where production is increasing by more than two and a half percent. At the same time, industries are lowering prices.
In Italy, in Germany, in England and in all European countries, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to production volumes and that we must organize production volumes and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of more than forty four of vegetable proteins and of thirty of the price of cereals.
The Parliament has already voted on the need here to ensure that the surplus value is distributed among the producers and that farmers are not victims of companies and the large distribution.

So I ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to come back to the questioning of the control of production. But at the same time, I say very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own houses, because there are countries that have respected the rules of the quotas and others that have not respected them.
And this is also what has made these quotas be called into question.
So there is a double responsibility of the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European railway space is a beautiful policy of European integration.
Here is a beautiful policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized because, in a state of emergency, Europe, finally, through this directive, is showing the way for a great policy of sustainable transport and is opening the way for a great policy of railway investment for employment.

I am pleased with the main measures taken in the organization of the railway network, the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract, thus stipulating the financing commitments of the

Railway infrastructure. But also, I welcome the establishment of financial flow transparency between managers and operators within integrated companies. The call for non-discriminatory access to certain

Services. And finally, I am pleased with the confirmation by the European Parliament of certain guarantees, especially on the social level, such as the absence of a reference to the minimum service and the total separation between the manager and the operator.

But allow me to raise a demand that we stop considering, especially by the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the only strategic horizon for the development of a single railway space, and thus decide on a European strategy of integrated investment that is favorable to employment in Europe.
Also, I would like to finish by asking you a question, Commissioner Kallas.
Three days after the European Council of June 28 and 29, after the validation of a growth pact of one hundred and twenty billion euros to revive the European economy.
Especially through investment in infrastructure. Can you tell us, Commissioner, what amount the European railway sector is likely to benefit from within the framework of this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address a question, certainly peripheral, but extremely important to my subject tonight.
These are the remarks made by Commissioner Mr. De Gucht in the International Trade Commission on Wednesday, June 20th.
I repeat, if you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not stop the procedure before the court.

Justice. Not only do these remarks seem to be ignorant of the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they show an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens that we represent.
Here is the time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. Well, at this time, many things have been said, so.
Mr. Commissioner, I would like to thank you very much.
Thanks to your persistence and procedural cunning, you allow us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and two million eight to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that we European elected officials are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you again for the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in the committee and who are still following us today.
I salute them. It is a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Commissioner, but in democracy, there is also another principle.
It is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take our responsibility and I would like to thank you tomorrow for taking your responsibility, your failure, the failure of your method of work.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I speak on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for the opinion of the Development Committee on the report of Mr Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to remind that when a country wishes to sanction a country that practices non sustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of coherence of policies with the objectives of development, it is crucial, in my opinion, that the measures adopted in the field of fishing do not undermine the development plans and strategies put in place by the European Union in these countries.
Mr Gallagher's report project reaffirms this important idea for our development commission, by foreseeing that measures must not be unjustified, nor even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when it adopts such measures, to respect this principle of coherence of policies with the objectives of development and that the level of development and the vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account. Thank you.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy should not be done again against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea thieves, the sole responsible for the poor health of the stocks, as environmentalist organizations and the European Commission claim, by encompassing all categories of fishing.

Of course, it is necessary to preserve fish stocks, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to make a living from their activity and to preserve the economic fabric, dynamism and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
However, the main measures of the European executive are once again moving in the direction of reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since nineteen eighty.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and sector concentration, or the total prohibition of rejections that professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but in its current form it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Karins, for this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of the bilateral negotiations in the field of energy between European countries and third states.
The agreement reached in trilogue will allow for a rapid implementation of the Commission's decision-making project, and for the sake of pragmatism, we can only rejoice.
The energy Europe is progressing, not fast enough, certainly, but it is progressing.
Strongly energy importing, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it became necessary to disseminate more widely to the European Commission the information relating to energy agreements, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus allow for the anticipation of energy supply problems.
I am pleased that the present decision does not create obligations regarding agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the issues of competition and competitiveness, we must protect the interests of our companies and the rules of protection of private contracts.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this issue.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very distant point with the Commission's basic proposal. No specific mention of the peripheral regions directly affected by the competition of Latin American countries. No automatic triggering.

Of the stabilization mechanism, no possibility offered to our assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as a possible unfair competitive advantage.
This is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the International Trade Commission.
Despite everything, this is not enough because we know that the thresholds for triggering these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide additional financial support in order to support the competitiveness of the production of community bananas.
Let us keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have high unemployment rates.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Gohren for his excellent report.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total public development aid and yet, as the deadline for the OMD approaches in 2015, even if some objectives seem to be met.

Achieved. We must ask ourselves the question of how to improve our aid, to make it more coherent in relation to our trade policy, in relation to our agricultural policy, in relation to our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on precise, measurable commitments and a short to medium-term timetable.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, and land grabbing force us to define new priorities, priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from decision-making organizations such as the WHO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
Just look at the markets that are opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of recent years, because the emerging countries of today were, a little while ago, developing countries.
From now on, as an essential economic power, these countries must also make their contribution to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than an expiration date. It will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as a simple financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions to ask that 2015 be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Thank you, Mr. President. The agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, from 2014, the choice of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per capita.
As Ms. Ashton reminded us, these questions are not only of an accounting nature, but they deserve a real political debate on the definition of our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Furthermore, this differentiated approach is not, in my opinion, in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries, which have achieved positive economic performance, should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in guaranteeing growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us salute the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall was falling.
And despite this, despite all the progress we have seen since the beginning of our debate, it must be said that the single act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality and economic liberalism.
So I would like to hear from you, Mr Barnier, Mr Commissioner, to indicate to us how we are going to build together a fairer, a more facilitative, a more protective Europe.

And there are a number of tracks, and I would like to hear from you on these tracks that are at the heart of the economic and social crisis, as we unfortunately know, tax harmonization, public services.
Protectors, minimum wage in Europe, establishment of strengthened cooperation, job creators, facilitate cross-border cooperation and develop a fair trade policy.
Here are the issues, I believe, twenty years later, that are before us.
I count on you, Commissioner, so that we can carry out this beautiful European construction policy together.

Thank you, Mr. President. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have closely followed the report by my colleague Regina Bastos on the twenty main issues of concern to citizens and businesses.
And we have discussed this report in connection with our debate on the 20 years of the internal market.
For twenty years already, the free movement of goods, services, and capital is supposed to be fully exercised within our space of life, exchange, and internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that, at the forefront of the concerns expressed by our European citizens, the issue of professional qualifications is highlighted, and that we really need to be particularly proactive and effective.

This is what our citizens are waiting for to truly achieve in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their titles, their skills, their professional qualifications, really faster, simpler, more efficient, less expensive.
"Ce n'est pas un problème mineur."

As a fictitious rapporteur of the PPE Group on this subject, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO Committee to truly respond to this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility for more Europe, that's what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, this year the petitions committee has acquired the right to be automatically associated for the hearing of European citizen initiatives.
This is for me the strong signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to which to turn in case of non respect of their rights, but it is also now the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I wish that the petitions committee could thus be considered more and more often as the privileged interlocutor of citizens in the European Parliament.
This problem of consideration is also found in the results of the commission's petitions.
Too often, we are called upon by citizens who are faced with legal loopholes on which we would like to take a stand. But while the problems are European,
The fact that the solutions should be European does not make us powerless, because subsidiarity is still not linked to European solutions due to a lack of national will.

I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when the rights of custody or visitation exceed national borders, that of Germany in this case.
Despite the blatant difficulties for many parents to see their children born from a binational union, we remain in Parliament still powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national mediator, especially from Germany, which sends a lot of petitions, on the model of the defender of rights in France, has not been followed with any effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a solution that reconciles European and national issues.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet citizens' expectations.
The European Year of Citizens' Rights 2013 will have to deal with the grievances of citizens. Listening is important, but we need the means to act to be.
